story:
Φίλες και φίλοι,

Η τοπική επιτροπή της διοργάνωσης του συνεδρίου της ILGA στην Αθήνα έβαλε ψηλά τον πήχη και ήδη με τις προσπάθειες που έχει καταβάλει η ILGA-Europe, το συνέδριο θα φιλοξενήσει 500 συνέδρους από όλον τον κόσμο, ρεκόρ της ιστορίας του πανευρωπαικού και παγκόσμιου κινήματος!

Σε αυτή τη προσπάθεια, η τοπική επιτροπή, αναζητά τρόπους και χρηματοδότηση, ώστε να μπορέσει να φέρει όσους και όσες περισσότερες ακτιβίστριες μπορεί, να βοηθήσει στο κομμάτι των εθελοντών, να βοηθήσει βαλκάνιους να έρθουν στο συνέδριο και να δείξει πάνω απ’ όλα τι σημαίνει Φιλοξενία στην Ελλάδα!

Θα εκτιμούσαμε βαθύτατα οποιαδήποτε στήριξη.

--------------------------------------------------------

Λίγα λόγια για το συνέδριο και την Ελληνική διοργάνωση

Η Πανευρωπαϊκή ομπρέλα των LGBTI (lesbian, gay, trans, bi, intersex) οργανώσεων, ILGA – Europe (με πάνω από 420 οργανώσεις - μέλη της σε όλη την Ευρώπη), θα διοργανώνει το ετήσιο συνέδριό της στην Αθήνα από τις 28 Οκτωβρίου 2015 έως τις 31 Οκτωβρίου 2015.

Το συνέδριο τελεί υπό την υψηλή αιγίδα της Ε.Ε., αλλά και Πρεσβειών κρατών – μελών της Ε.Ε. στην Ελλάδα.

Ο συντονισμός και η διοργάνωση του συνεδρίου στην Ελλάδα, πραγματοποιείται από την ΟΛΚΕ (Ομοφυλοφιλική και Λεσβιακή Κοινότητα Ελλάδας), σε συνεργασία με άλλες LGBTI οργανώσεις και ομάδες της χώρας. Η διεύρυνση σε άλλες οργανώσεις, της Τοπικής Οργανωτικής Επιτροπής, γίνεται για πρώτη φορά σε ετήσιο συνέδριο της ILGA – Europe, έπειτα από πρωτοβουλία της ΟΛΚΕ. Εκτός από τις LGBTI οργανώσεις που συμμετέχουν στην Τοπική Επιτροπή (ΣΥΔ, Queer Trans, Οικογένειες Ουράνιο Τόξο, Ομοφοβία και Τρανσφοβία στην Εκπαίδευση, ΛΟΑΤ ΑμεΑ, Athens Pride, Thessaloniki Pride), συμμετέχουν και άλλες ΜΚΟ που ασχολούνται με τα ανθρώπινα δικαιώματα (Praksis, Θετική Φωνή), καθώς και εθελοντές που συμμετείχαν ενεργά στους Ολυμπιακούς Αγώνες Αθήνα 2004 και Παγκόσμιους Αγώνες των Special Olympics 2011.

story:
Short Summary

I am Nia Burks. I’m a video artist.  I investigate identity constructs, personal relationships, and collective memory on the web. I use appropriated videos that I find on YouTube to re-create and re-define their meaning and existence so that I can learn more about how we use the social web.

I appropriate footage because figuring out the web is a rapidly moving target and I believe the people who use it best define its purpose. My goal with art is to learn more about how we use the internet as a tool for connectivity, ask questions, and come to a few conclusions before the next set of questions come barreling in.

Right now, I am preparing to have a solo exhibition with a new body of work titled Standardized Authenticity. This new body of work will show in Berlin, Germany concurrent with the Berlin Biennale at Art Claims Impulse Gallery in Kreuxburg. An opening, artist talk and a live performance will take place on April 27th and the show will be up for the following month.

I am in a crucial developmental stage for the work. I need many many hours to put the finishing touches on this body of video work and I need backers to help fund this project and make this artist talk and performance happen.

What We Need & What You Get

My goal is to raise $1500 to help cover the total cost of production and travel. Your contributions will not go unrewarded. The perk system I’ve created is intended to not only thank you for your generosity, but also further this research by allowing me to directly collaborate and respond the medium I work in---you and me, the web users. For every donation over $50 there is a personalized perk. I did this, not only for obvious awesome perk related reasons, but also because my work deals with the personal that’s been mediated. I want to highlight that mediated connection while also trying to bring back the idea of a unique interaction between two people.

For $10, I will add your name to my website as a contributor. For $20, I will add your name to my website, and send you a handwritten postcard from Berlin when I arrive for the exhibition opening. For $50, you get all of the above, plus a 5x7 mini show poster signed with a unique Photobooth shot of the gallery and me before the opening. For $100, you get all of the above, a personalized thank you video postcard that Ill post to YouTube from the gallery and an 8x10 print of a unique computer glitch that I will screen shot while I am abroad so that you have a physical print of a specific and ephemeral moment in time. My computer makes these for me pretty often and I catch them and name them.  For $250, you’ll be invited to a pre- opening curatorial tour via BlogTv with me containing new work not yet on the web, and receive a personalized 11x14 print of one of my Facebook layered default prints created from YOUR facebook photos. For $500, you’ll get all of the above, plus a 30 second unique piece of video art that you create the prompt for. We will discuss the prompt and idea in a one on one meeting via skype upon my return from Berlin. This way, you and I, the web users, can directly collaborate on the subject of an artwork, which I have not yet done in my art practice yet.

The Impact

This show will help get my work out during a very important time of year: the Berlin Biennale. Having this exhibition and talk at Art Claims Impulse during the same time that the Berlin Biennale will give my work countless eyes and attention, and thus help contribute to an ever changing and shifting dialogue that is the internet.
 

Other Ways You Can Help

Don't have any money but still want to contribute? Thats ok. Share this link, pass along my website and tell folks about the show! Find the Standardized Authenticity Page on Facebook (look out, it'll be up soon!) and share it with friends.

story:
Our goal is to revitalise an iconic and historically significant building in Glasgow, Scotland - by developing it into a vibrant venue, bringing art, music, culture and life to a disadvantaged area of the city.


Who we are and our campaign

The Charles Rennie Mackintosh Society is an independent, non-profit making charity, established in 1973 to promote the awareness of the Scottish architect, artist and designer, Charles Rennie Mackintosh and support the preservation and protection of Mackintosh's buildings.

One of the many not-for-profit activities of the Society has been to rescue and restore his only Church, when it fell into disuse in 1976 and was no longer required by the Church of Scotland.  The building was in danger of being lost and the Society stepped in to save it.  With many renovations and a major restoration project the Society aims to protect and preserve this important building for future generations.

We recognise that the building, while having such historic relevance to the area through its iconic architect, is also a beautiful and unique building that can create the perfect setting for the arts.

Our campaign is designed to help us develop this stunning site and take advantage of the building's excellent natural acoustic qualities for the use of concerts, gigs, exhibitions and shows. This will not only help to keep the building alive, but also creates a new and vibrant arts centre in one of the areas of highest multiple deprivation in Glasgow.

What we need

To achieve our goal we need to raise £10,000 to put towards transforming this venue into a usable and accessible area for performing artists, musicians and events.

The money will be used in three key ways:

To create additional performance space.
Install stage lighting, to help create the right atmosphere that will enhance any type of performance, exhibition or art show.
To provide a quality grand piano that will give musicians access to use the venue as a performing space.
***This will not only help open up the building for arts use, but also give free access to local music students to use the space for rehearsals and lunchtime concerts.***

If we did not reach our goal of £10,000, we would assess the most effective way to use what money we have raised to fulfill one or two of these aspects.

All of the work that we do within the building is in consultation with Historic Scotland and conservation specialists.

 

What you can get - PERKS!!

          £7         =               

                                            Mackintosh Greetings Cards

 

          £15       =              

                                         Mackintosh Church china mug

  

          £25       =         

                                            Mackintosh watercolour print

 

          £50       =             

                                                Paper Sculpture Kit 

 

          £100     =                   

                                            Signed Framed Photograph

 

          £125     =                   

                                       40th Anniversary Pin - limited Edition

          £150     =                  

                                             Personal tour of the church

 

        £200     =               + £50                                                  

                                      VIP Membership + £50 on events

                 

          £300    =  

                                      Framed Jessie M King Bookplate



         £600     =        

                                      Tutored architectural photography session

£2000  =        

 Exclusive Overnight Stay at the Mackintosh Church to hunt for the Ghost of Mackintosh

 

          £5000   =                         

                                        Wedding at Mackintosh Church

 

 

The Impact

By contributing to this cause we will be able to create a facility that will enhance a heritage building and bring life to the area it is situated in, by encouraging a world of arts, music and culture to perform here. This will bring associated benefits to the local community, local artists and performers and encourages a sustainable use of this unique heritage site.

Moreover your efforts will help music students from the area to develop their talents for free.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand more than most, that often money can be limited and would not wish you to contribute if you are unable.

However, you could help us by spreading the word. You can shout it from the rooftops, proclaim it over the dinner table, announce it to a stranger, OR if you could share a link on your Facebook or twitter page then we would be very grateful.

Indiegogo also have some great share tools for spreading the word.

story:
What is PlunderFest?

By the upmost straight forward meaning of its name "Take the festival", by all means, we want you to do just that! We are giving you ((anyone attending)) safe artistic freedom as artists to spread your wings.

You are encouraged to go all out, live your dream, be inspiring, be jaw dropping, And CREATE!

Plunderfest is much, much more then a music or art festival.... PlunderFest is an experience!

There are two types of people who attend our festival. The watcher, and the participant.  We can promise you, by the end of the weekend you're a participant.

While we are NOT a non-profit, all proceeds gained from the festival go back into its self to create a better experience for the following year.  If our proceeds ever reach a million dollars.... you better believe we are putting on one hell of a million dollar show the following year! 

We have a pretty huge goal to do something for the Midwest that has never been done before.....   Let us explain how and why....

Usually a typical concert takes place in a gated venue.  If there is to be camping, it is usually in a separate housing area OUTSIDE of the gated music area. Not a very pleasant walk to get back and forth and it also becomes a hassle to get in and out of a secured zone for the patron.

Usually a typical concert has specified hours of am-pm and once the music stops... you are left to your own device, shuffled out of the music area as quickly as can be and gates are locked till the next concert day.  The in-between is left to your own mind. Not always entirely fun..

These are the first 2 things Plunderfest sought after as a foundation for change.
We have one major zone.... Everything happens within ONE area. All festival activities take place inside ONE GIANT FESTIVAL GROUNDS. Leaves out all complication and the annoyance that goes with it. 

NOW... here is the foundation that makes PlunderFest what it is!

PARTICIPATION AND CREATION! 

Creating a piece that shows who and what you are... and allowing others to safely view your dream in a scope that holds no time limits nor boundaries outside of safety. 

To the musical artists: 

We offer the creative gift of our stages to you.  We offer you a chance to play our gorgeous stages in the deep Midwest woods to present the best of your talents. We do our best to provide you the exposure you so greatly deserve. Hard thought and countless hours of planning goes in to this process each year. Our goal here is to ensure magical experiences happen by day and into the evening in our concert area with musical appearances from artists through out the world. 

Large consideration goes into the UP AND COMING LOCAL musicians of the Midwest. We wish for your everlasting success in fulfilling your dreams as an artist.

 

The real magic happens everywhere else....  Sculptures, art installations, theme camp built stages, fun houses, cool down areas, simple to amazingly complex structures that have full interaction with you! YOU are the artist, YOU are the patron, YOU are the festival... YOU are what we care about and YOU are the reason the magic exists!

Our musical gifts follow the guidelines of the law for keeping hours of timed sound.... HOWEVER once the music is over there is playground of un-measurable possibility only limited by the artist.  If you want to see it, we encourage you to build it and share it!

Think about it...

You may not even be interested in the music but your whole purpose might be to create a fun house, a giant castle, a water station, a fire-spewing dragon.... 

To have a festival that truly caters to EVERY ONE of all ages!

MAGIC!!!!!!!

THE SUPER HUGE POINT we have to stress is the shier size of the venue we are currently calling home.  

It's literally MILES of open fields, trees, and gorgeous land!!!  The ability to grow this festival into the largest Midwest festival...  it isn't just a dream.. THIS IS a very very REAL thing! 

We NEED your help to make this possible.

What does PlunderFest provide for the artists who attend?

We provide a safe space that allows you as an artist to create your wildest dream creation.  It doesn't matter if you're a band and just want to create a large-scale stage show, or a visual artist who just wishes to create something magical.  PlunderFest will find a home for you on its massive grounds. 

We would love to be able to help fund your creations for the show in the future. Outside of functional production costs we will some day have an overage.  Some of that overage will then be presented as an applicable artists fund.  

Lets say you have a creative concept that you would love to build for PlunderFest and this creation could be used to help benefit you as an artist AFTER the show.  You could put in for a PlunderFest grant and we could help fund your individual project.  This in turn would help us create a larger spectacle for the festival and allow you to grow as an artist, allowing you to take a piece of the festival home with you, your personal plunder. 

What does your pledge mean to PlunderFest?

We dream in HUGE. We have always taken the words "Go big or go home" quite seriously. After 3 years of hard dedication in supporting the artists, we need your help to launch this project into hyperspace.

If we are able to reach a goal of $28,000.00 (set at $30,000.00 to allow for fees).

We can build a world first stage light show display.  
This stage display would consist of a 28 feet of High Definition LED fabric and DMX controlled moving stage lights. 
((Think DaftPunk, DeadMau5, PrettyLights, AmonTobin))

With your pledges we would be able to purchase enough sectional LED fabric to cover a large scale outdoor stage, and roughly 20 Intelligent moving lights.

This concept lighting rig would allow us to change around our stage show each year, creating a different stage illusion, without adding to our production cost... 
allowing us to cater our production value of the show even further.

We would also be taking this rig on tour and bringing it to as many festivals around the nation as we can possibly schedule. We want you to see our passion in person.

We have already received sponsorship from the manufactures to help reduce the cost of this production to an affordable cost... however we need your help to be able to bring this to production to a reality.  

We know our goal of $30,000.00 is a large number to grasp at... so we have broken it down to its raw bare minimal functioning cost per panel.  

Each Panel will cost us roughly $4,500.00 in production and delivery.
((lowering in cost of coarse if we are able to purchase more panels at one given time.))

We have set our goal at $5,000.00 to allow for fees, and stretched our goal timeframe to the max possible in order to fundraise as much as possible to reach our total goal. 

If we receive anything above and beyond the amount we seek 
((as $30,000.00 barely scrapes the barrel of what we could do with the money...))
it will go directly into the festival funding to create a better show for everyone. 

Other artist suggested projects include but are not limited to : 

Solar LED's to light up the floor and trees.
Solar color changing jellyfish to hang in trees. 
Wood for our large wooden phoenix remembrance sculpture we burn on Friday, Supplies to donate to our medical staff, (as they donate free time to us.)
Advertising supplies,
Gifts to give our ticket holders upon entree,
Larger PlunderFest produced structures to build for ticket holders,
starting our art fund FOR OTHER artists who don't have the money to fully fund a dream project

((we wish to pay it all forward))

 

 

 If you wish to contact us for any reason you may do so at the following:

Plunderfest@gmail.com 

http://www.facebook.com/plunderfest

We dearly appreciate your time, and thank you far in advance! "I wish I could put it into writing what this festival as a whole means to me.. To be able to give such a huge gift.... but I simply can't.....  You just have to experience the magic to understand, then it will never leave your heart, just as it's never left mine." -Sean Farrell / Founder of PlunderFest
story_txt:
What is PlunderFest?
By the upmost straight forward meaning of its name "Take the festival", by all means, we want you to do just that! We are giving you ((anyone attending)) safe artistic freedom as artists to spread your wings.
You are encouraged to go all out, live your dream, be inspiring, be jaw dropping, And CREATE!
Plunderfest is much, much more then a music or art festival.... PlunderFest is an experience!
There are two types of people who attend our festival. The watcher, and the participant.  We can promise you, by the end of the weekend you're a participant.
While we are NOT a non-profit, all proceeds gained from the festival go back into its self to create a better experience for the following year.  If our proceeds ever reach a million dollars.... you better believe we are putting on one hell of a million dollar show the following year! 
We have a pretty huge goal to do something for the Midwest that has never been done before.....   Let us explain how and why....
Usually a typical concert takes place in a gated venue.  If there is to be camping, it is usually in a separate housing area OUTSIDE of the gated music area. Not a very pleasant walk to get back and forth and it also becomes a hassle to get in and out of a secured zone for the patron.
Usually a typical concert has specified hours of am-pm and once the music stops... you are left to your own device, shuffled out of the music area as quickly as can be and gates are locked till the next concert day.  The in-between is left to your own mind. Not always entirely fun..
These are the first 2 things Plunderfest sought after as a foundation for change.We have one major zone.... Everything happens within ONE area. All festival activities take place inside ONE GIANT FESTIVAL GROUNDS. Leaves out all complication and the annoyance that goes with it. 
NOW... here is the foundation that makes PlunderFest what it is!PARTICIPATION AND CREATION! Creating a piece that shows who and what you are... and allowing others to safely view your dream in a scope that holds no time limits nor boundaries outside of safety. 
To the musical artists: 
We offer the creative gift of our stages to you.  We offer you a chance to play our gorgeous stages in the deep Midwest woods to present the best of your talents. We do our best to provide you the exposure you so greatly deserve. Hard thought and countless hours of planning goes in to this process each year. Our goal here is to ensure magical experiences happen by day and into the evening in our concert area with musical appearances from artists through out the world. Large consideration goes into the UP AND COMING LOCAL musicians of the Midwest. We wish for your everlasting success in fulfilling your dreams as an artist.
 
The real magic happens everywhere else....  Sculptures, art installations, theme camp built stages, fun houses, cool down areas, simple to amazingly complex structures that have full interaction with you! YOU are the artist, YOU are the patron, YOU are the festival... YOU are what we care about and YOU are the reason the magic exists!
Our musical gifts follow the guidelines of the law for keeping hours of timed sound.... HOWEVER once the music is over there is playground of un-measurable possibility only limited by the artist.  If you want to see it, we encourage you to build it and share it!
Think about it...
You may not even be interested in the music but your whole purpose might be to create a fun house, a giant castle, a water station, a fire-spewing dragon.... 
To have a festival that truly caters to EVERY ONE of all ages!
MAGIC!!!!!!!
THE SUPER HUGE POINT we have to stress is the shier size of the venue we are currently calling home.  
It's literally MILES of open fields, trees, and gorgeous land!!!  The ability to grow this festival into the largest Midwest festival...  it isn't just a dream.. THIS IS a very very REAL thing! 
We NEED your help to make this possible.
What does PlunderFest provide for the artists who attend?
We provide a safe space that allows you as an artist to create your wildest dream creation.  It doesn't matter if you're a band and just want to create a large-scale stage show, or a visual artist who just wishes to create something magical.  PlunderFest will find a home for you on its massive grounds. 
We would love to be able to help fund your creations for the show in the future. Outside of functional production costs we will some day have an overage.  Some of that overage will then be presented as an applicable artists fund.  
Lets say you have a creative concept that you would love to build for PlunderFest and this creation could be used to help benefit you as an artist AFTER the show.  You could put in for a PlunderFest grant and we could help fund your individual project.  This in turn would help us create a larger spectacle for the festival and allow you to grow as an artist, allowing you to take a piece of the festival home with you, your personal plunder. 
What does your pledge mean to PlunderFest?
We dream in HUGE. We have always taken the words "Go big or go home" quite seriously. After 3 years of hard dedication in supporting the artists, we need your help to launch this project into hyperspace.
If we are able to reach a goal of $28,000.00 (set at $30,000.00 to allow for fees).
We can build a world first stage light show display.  This stage display would consist of a 28 feet of High Definition LED fabric and DMX controlled moving stage lights. ((Think DaftPunk, DeadMau5, PrettyLights, AmonTobin))
With your pledges we would be able to purchase enough sectional LED fabric to cover a large scale outdoor stage, and roughly 20 Intelligent moving lights.
This concept lighting rig would allow us to change around our stage show each year, creating a different stage illusion, without adding to our production cost... allowing us to cater our production value of the show even further.
We would also be taking this rig on tour and bringing it to as many festivals around the nation as we can possibly schedule. We want you to see our passion in person.
We have already received sponsorship from the manufactures to help reduce the cost of this production to an affordable cost... however we need your help to be able to bring this to production to a reality.  
We know our goal of $30,000.00 is a large number to grasp at... so we have broken it down to its raw bare minimal functioning cost per panel.  
Each Panel will cost us roughly $4,500.00 in production and delivery.((lowering in cost of coarse if we are able to purchase more panels at one given time.))
We have set our goal at $5,000.00 to allow for fees, and stretched our goal timeframe to the max possible in order to fundraise as much as possible to reach our total goal. 
If we receive anything above and beyond the amount we seek ((as $30,000.00 barely scrapes the barrel of what we could do with the money...))it will go directly into the festival funding to create a better show for everyone. 
Other artist suggested projects include but are not limited to : Solar LED's to light up the floor and trees.Solar color changing jellyfish to hang in trees. Wood for our large wooden phoenix remembrance sculpture we burn on Friday, Supplies to donate to our medical staff, (as they donate free time to us.)Advertising supplies,Gifts to give our ticket holders upon entree,Larger PlunderFest produced structures to build for ticket holders,starting our art fund FOR OTHER artists who don't have the money to fully fund a dream project((we wish to pay it all forward))
 
 
 If you wish to contact us for any reason you may do so at the following:
Plunderfest@gmail.com 
http://www.facebook.com/plunderfest
We dearly appreciate your time, and thank you far in advance! "I wish I could put it into writing what this festival as a whole means to me.. To be able to give such a huge gift.... but I simply can't.....  You just have to experience the magic to understand, then it will never leave your heart, just as it's never left mine." -Sean Farrell / Founder of PlunderFest

story:
The Literary Festival is a free arts and literature festival that will take place in West Covina, California.  The Festival will bring dozens of writers and artists to Southern California to read their writing and share their artwork.  The festival will run from February 15th to 17th, 2013.  

I'm Scott Creley, I'm a curator along with John Brantingham, Ann Brantingham, and Elder Zamora.  We've made bringing this festival to West Covina our full-time passion.  We've put thousands of hours into planning and executing this festival in the past year and a half.  We've even started a 501c(3).  Now we need your help. 

We are bringing poets and writers to the San Gabriel Valley to so we can finally have the kind of festival that other communities experience and we deserve. There will be hundreds of poets and writers sharing the work, and the best part is that everyone in the community can read their work as well.

We can bring the world of arts and culture to West Covina. There is as much talent and passion in our corner of Los Angeles as there is in Paris or London or New York. We just don’t have as many opportunities to express ourselves. This is our opportunity to change that!

What We Need & What You Get

Running a free, public festival isn’t easy.  The City of West Covina has donated us the operating space, but we have many (many!) operational costs we still need to cover:

What we need --

  • Security

We need to pay to have the Festival Area guarded during the night (that way nobody makes off with all the art and literature!).

  • Author/Artist fees

Since we want to bring the best writers and artists possible to West Covina, we need to pay them a little to help them to travel here to
West Covina and buy a sandwich or two.

  • Web Space

We run a very fancy website, but apparently need to pay for web space. Go see the website, it’s beautiful (and worth it!)

  • Promotion

We’re running the festival in an area that doesn’t have a traditional “art culture” & we need to make sure that everyone knows about the festival and has access to it.  This means passing out fliers (lots of them), 

  • Electricity

We’ll need to run sound, record the festival, and have the lights on after dark.  This means we’ll need to rent a few generators! Also, some of the writers are afraid of the dark.

  • Furniture Rentals

We’ve got to have places for artists to set their art and writers to scribble that writing.  Artists gonna art. Writers gonna write.

What you get --
Donors will receive the following:

  • $10 (250 available) “Patron” Donor Package
    • A Limited-Edition SGVLF button for donors (people love our buttons, check this one out. Yours will be one of these.
    • Your name on the “Patron” donor list on SGVLF.com
  • $25 (100 available) “Silver Patron” Donor Package
    • A Limited-Edition SGVLF button for donors (people love our buttons, check this one out. Yours will be one of these.
    • Your name on the “Silver Patron” donor list on SGVLF.com
    • Early Access to a free download of video from the San Gabriel Valley Literary Festival.
  • $100 (40 available) “Gold Patron” Donor Package
    • All the above plus: A signed copy of one in-print paperback edition of a book of your choice from a SGVLF 2013 Author.
  • $1000 (4 available) "Poet Laureate" Donor Package
    • All the above, and a V.I.P pass for the weekend, two additional signedbooks. and a luncheon with the SGVLF board and authors.  
    • A unique broadside from an SGVLF 2013 author of your choice by artist Daniel Cuesta.   
  • $2000 (Only 1 available) Visionary Master Donor Package
    • (Very!)VIP Status -- Individual photos with 3 festival authors of your choice by professional photographer. (must attend festival to collect -- contact us if unable to attend)
    • Custom Broadside by artist Daniel Cuesta (see example)
    • Five signed (in-print) books from 2013 SGVLF authors of your choice
    • Five versions of SGVLF donor button. 
    • Almost too much to list!  See the perk to the right.

 

  • Any amount of money will help. If we don’t reach our goals, the funds we do have will go to bringing in generators and paying for security.

The Impact

Despite having a rich and vibrant creative community, the San Gabriel Valley and its neighboring cities do not have an annual literature or arts festival.  When you accept this invitation to help us, you are doing more than dropping a few digital bucks in our coffers, you are helping to invigorate the literary community east of Los Angeles, promote literacy, and establish a yearly tradition that will help others share the gift of the arts for generations. We want to give our area an outlet, and we want to support our local artists and writers and share their awesome work with the world.  We know we can give the Inland Empire and San Gabriel Valley a global voice.

When people in our area want to write or to see writers, they usually leave town. They go to Long Beach or San Francisco or New York. They shouldn’t have to. We have talent and even genius in our backyard. Help us to celebrate that genius. We have brought writing programs like Writer’s Weekend to Mt. SAC, but we want to bring something to everyone in the area, not just our students. Everyone can join in on the festival. Everyone can be a part of it.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t donate, you can still do a lot for us.

1.)We run an Amazon.com clickthrough -- use our clickthrough any time you shop on Amazon.com, Amazon will donate a small portion of the proceeds to SGVLF (at no cost to you or the vendor).
2.)Spread the word.  Visit our website for easily-shared banners, flyers, and twitter updates.
3.)Speaking of Twitter, follow us on Twitter, become a facebook fan, and subscribe to our youtube.
4.)Use the Indiegogo sharing tools
5.)Come to the Festival on February 15th, 16th, & 17th!

Curators/Non-profit board

I'm Scott Creley. I've worked to enhance literacy Southern California communities since I was a teenager.  I'm a professor at Whittier College, and I am also the president of the San Gabriel Valley Literary Festival. I do our web-design, organization, and hundreds upon hundreds of spreadsheets.  Hundreds.  So many spreadsheets.

I’m Ann Brantingham, a director at the San Gabriel Valley Literary Festival. I have spent my life in the San Gabriel Valley and am the creator and owner of Spout Hill Press a local small press focused entirely on publishing novellas.

I’m John Brantingham. I’ve been an English professor at Mt. SAC where I help to coordinate the creative writing programs since 1998. I’ve brought poets to Mt. SAC. Now I want to bring them to our community.  


Elder Zamora is a poet and educator.  He handles the contracts, non-profit tax aspects, and travel for our writers.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Chalkmaster Dave and i've been making my living as a sidewalk chalk artist/painter for 20 years. I've had the privilege of traveling to diffierent countries for my work as well as across Canada many times. It hasn't always been easy, at one point i literally was down to $1.79... i bought one piece of black chalk... started drawing on the sidewalk and made a few dollars... i used that to buy a few more pieces of colored chalk...and now, now im Chalkmaster Dave and have dined with movie stars, travelled the world for my art, partied with rock bands and done shows for politicians in front of thousands... and been welcmed into homes from strangers i've met on the internet who've now become life long friends. i'm positive there will still be some rough times every now and then,  but i would choose to do nothing else if i were given a second chance.

My goal is to make a documentary called "Operation: Chalk the Nation"
 as well as a book when it's all done.

about 4 Years ago i developed a fear of flying which lead me to drive everywhere i needed to go for my gigs. Over time i realized how much of a rush we are to get everywhere that we rarely take the time to enjoy the trip. We bypass so much by hoping from one airport to another. This country is absolutely stunning in it's geography and contains people from all walks of life with history and culture few people are aware of and through my specialized tpye of art performed at festivals i've been blessed to have seen and experienced this country in a way only a handful of us have. I want to show everyne i can through this documentary the power and the privilege art has in our lives and how its accepted, or not, by different people in different places. Along the way we learn about this country in a hands on approach and the adventure that this will undoubtedly become. This idea of mine is so important that i'm willing to give up most of my summer to do this...the summer is where i make the bulk of m money to survive my winters, but im willing to risk not making much money this season to make this documentary because i see a value here beyond just the money...i see the potential to open eyes and inspire and bring a view of this country to people in a way they've never seen before.

What We Need & What You Get

the goal is $25,000. After fees for this site  and unexpected suprises I'm likely going to need a little more to pull it all together properly but im banking on being able to make some money with tips and or selling prints of my art between now and the end of the journey.

Gas i'm estimating to be around $2400, Equipment and supplies i estimate $3200, food and lodgings every few days so i can shower is going to be about $5500, i've estimated $2000 for vehicle maintenance as over 12,000 kilometres of driving is definitely going to do some wear and tear, 2 months of bills ie rent etc is $6200.

so without anything going wrong and zero issues along the way i would need at least $19,300 and i haven't even added cost of  a volunteer to film me and their food... so i can see $22,000 as an absolute minimum while still needing to sell some art on the way.
 Whatever i can raise i will use to make the best Documentary possible this summer... i'm aiming for the stars on this one even if it's against the odds and most will tell me this is impossible to raise.

 

Donate $10 or more and i will personally thank you by name in the documentary and in the book.

Donate $30 i will give you a signed print of my art.

Donate $60 and recieve 3 signed prints of my art.

Donate $100 and recieve a signed copy of the book as well as 3 signed prints of my art.

Donate $500 and recieve a signed copy of the book, 3 signed prints of my art, and an original 12"x16" painting from me.

Donate $1500 and get all of the above and i'll stop off at your place of work or residence to do a personal sidewalk art piece just for you which will be in the documentary and be listed as an associate producer in "Operation: Chalk the Nation"

 

 

The Impact

One of the reasons i want to do this, even though it will take away profit from me this season, is to show everyone how wonderful this country is and how incredibly fortunate i have been over the years to make my living as an artist. I worked hard, and sacrificed a lot to make it but theres no way i could've made it without the support of people over the years. many times i;ve been down and broke and had no clue how i was going to get through, and then what seemed like out of the blue, someone backed me up, or bought my art, or showed me the way. Becoming a successful artist isn't about being the "best" artist... it's about the support you have from the people and your fans. I am not the best...there are many far more skilled than i am... but for whatever reason i was lucky to have support of people and i work hard to keep that support by giving back when i can and supporting other artists as well. Being an artist is not a linear goal for me... it's not about a financial goal so much as it is about bulding good connections with people. So long as there's enough money to pay the bills im happy living the rest of my life like the silly headed goofy artist that i am with the privilege of meeting and experiencing many more things with and for the people who support my craft.

I've taken on some big projects in my life... raised thousands of dollars  for animal shelters, a personal friends cancer medication, community projects, donated my time teaching art to kids and donating work for fundraisers to sick kids hospital, given away much art and supported other peoples goals... not for glory, but because i believe we're in this life together and if i dont share my gift the way others have shared with me then i simply don't deserve the support.

If you would like to learn more about me and what i do check me out on facebook, chalkmaster dave, ... i'm rough around the edges, i'm not extremely well spoken and sometimes i say too many silly things as stand up comedy is a little obby of mine so im always saying something weird lol. In the end... i'm just a guy whos had some glory thanks to others and this country i live in... if i can turn this experience into something positive for others and myself then i look forward to the challenge.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate but still want to help... please share this. Show your friends, co workers, any rich people who like funding cool stuff..... if you're on facebook share it. I sure would appreciate it. And remember to keep checking because if this works out this thing is going to be a hit.

the goal is $25,000. After fees for this site  and unexpected suprises I'm likely going to need a little more to pull it all together properly but im banking on being able to make some money with tips and or selling prints of my art between now and the end of the journey.
Gas i'm estimating to be around $2400, Equipment and supplies i estimate $3200, food and lodgings every few days so i can shower is going to be about $5500, i've estimated $2000 for vehicle maintenance as over 12,000 kilometres of driving is definitely going to do some wear and tear, 2 months of bills ie rent etc is $6200.
so without anything going wrong and zero issues along the way i would need at least $19,300 and i haven't even added cost of  a volunteer to film me and their food... so i can see $22,000 as an absolute minimum while still needing to sell some art on the way. Whatever i can raise i will use to make the best Documentary possible this summer... i'm aiming for the stars on this one even if it's against the odds and most will tell me this is impossible to raise.
 
Donate $10 or more and i will personally thank you by name in the documentary and in the book.
Donate $30 i will give you a signed print of my art.
Donate $60 and recieve 3 signed prints of my art.
Donate $100 and recieve a signed copy of the book as well as 3 signed prints of my art.
Donate $500 and recieve a signed copy of the book, 3 signed prints of my art, and an original 12"x16" painting from me.
Donate $1500 and get all of the above and i'll stop off at your place of work or residence to do a personal sidewalk art piece just for you which will be in the documentary and be listed as an associate producer in "Operation: Chalk the Nation"
 
 


The Impact
One of the reasons i want to do this, even though it will take away profit from me this season, is to show everyone how wonderful this country is and how incredibly fortunate i have been over the years to make my living as an artist. I worked hard, and sacrificed a lot to make it but theres no way i could've made it without the support of people over the years. many times i;ve been down and broke and had no clue how i was going to get through, and then what seemed like out of the blue, someone backed me up, or bought my art, or showed me the way. Becoming a successful artist isn't about being the "best" artist... it's about the support you have from the people and your fans. I am not the best...there are many far more skilled than i am... but for whatever reason i was lucky to have support of people and i work hard to keep that support by giving back when i can and supporting other artists as well. Being an artist is not a linear goal for me... it's not about a financial goal so much as it is about bulding good connections with people. So long as there's enough money to pay the bills im happy living the rest of my life like the silly headed goofy artist that i am with the privilege of meeting and experiencing many more things with and for the people who support my craft.
I've taken on some big projects in my life... raised thousands of dollars  for animal shelters, a personal friends cancer medication, community projects, donated my time teaching art to kids and donating work for fundraisers to sick kids hospital, given away much art and supported other peoples goals... not for glory, but because i believe we're in this life together and if i dont share my gift the way others have shared with me then i simply don't deserve the support.
If you would like to learn more about me and what i do check me out on facebook, chalkmaster dave, ... i'm rough around the edges, i'm not extremely well spoken and sometimes i say too many silly things as stand up comedy is a little obby of mine so im always saying something weird lol. In the end... i'm just a guy whos had some glory thanks to others and this country i live in... if i can turn this experience into something positive for others and myself then i look forward to the challenge.


Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't donate but still want to help... please share this. Show your friends, co workers, any rich people who like funding cool stuff..... if you're on facebook share it. I sure would appreciate it. And remember to keep checking because if this works out this thing is going to be a hit.

story:
A Lotus for you, the enlightened one will be. (Buddha)

Hello all! My name is Junichiro (Jun) Ishida, a visual artist based in Brooklyn, NY. I am excited to launch this fundraising campaign to cover the cost of my art residency in Wyoming to create a new body of work!

I was born in the port city, Kobe, Japan, and came to the US two decades ago. My art intertwines with my spiritual practice, Buddhism, and its aim is to bring tranquility in life.

I paint the Lotus flower as a metaphor for the process of the enlightenment. The lotus flower grows in mud and rises from it to bloom. Likewise, people can bloom into the state of enlightenment by overcoming muddy negative thoughts and emotions. 

I was accepted to the Jentel art residency, just outside of Sheridan, Wyoming for this winter. I am going there on November 15 and come back on December 15th. I am very excited about the opportunity ahead. Getting accepted in a residency is very important for me since It allows me to create bigger size of work than what my Brooklyn apartment can accomodate.

 People often ask me how long does my piece take to be made. I have pieces that I bring one residency to another, which sometimes are put in suspension for more than a year. Being accepted residency is a competitive matter. One needs to prove that the project is worthwhile by presenting previous works and a proposal, to be judged by selection committee members whom are respected in their field. 

 The Jentel residency will provide living space, studio, and a small stipend to cover my food for one month residency. I am very excited and thankful that I can have this very focused time to create my craft. But I need your help.

During the residency, I intended to further develop my "lotus" series of painting , and create a  "Mandala" installation, which is an interactive assembled piece on which viewers can practice walking meditation to get the sense of serenity and calmness.


What you get and what I need:

I am offering a lot of goodies for you in different levels. I need to do this fundraising to cover my transportation, materials, and shipping cost. 

For most of rewards, you will receive original art works. You can look at the right side of this page or below to see more detailed information about each gift. 

Here are the goodies:

$8 Adventurer

I have a vast collection of postcards in different subject matters from all over the world. I will write you a thank you note on a selection from my postcard collection.


$15 Appreciator

I will send you one greeting card featuring a piece from my one liner series, plus a thank you note from Wyoming on a selection from my post card collection.

$30 Collector

I will send you three greeting cards, featuring my featuring piece from my "One Liner Series" series, plus a thank you note from Wyoming a selection from my post card collection.

$50 Connoisseur

I will send you sets of three greeting card (6 total) featuring my art  from the "One Liner Series" plus a thank you note from Wyoming on a selection from my post card collection.

$75 Patron

I will send you sets of three greeting card (6 total) featuring my art  from the "One Liner Series" plus a thank you note from Wyoming on a selection from my post card collection, and a calligraphy of your name in Japanese.

And here are "One Liner Series" paintings.

$100 Lucky winner

A brand new drawing on 2.5" x 3.5" paper, plus 3 greeting cards, plus a thank you note from Wyoming on a selection from my post card collection.

$150 Seeker

You will receive a new one-of-a-kind "Mono-eye" mandala painting, 4.5" x 6.5" on 8" x 10" paper (or this one), plus a thank you note from Wyoming on a selection from my post card collection, and 3 "One-Liner" greeting cards.

$175 Treasure hunter

Original drawing on paper similar to the one below, 4.5" x 6.5" on 8" x 10".

Or chose one from here

Plus a thank you note from Wyoming on a selection from my postcard collection and 3 greeting cards from the "One-Liner" collection.


$200 Dinner guests

I will make you rare Japanese food for two that most likely you will not see on your Japanese restaurant menu. (Or I will make you your favorite kind)
Plus a thank you note from Wyoming on a selection from my postcard collection and 3 greeting cards from the "One-Liner" collection.
Travel expenses outside of New York City not included.


$250 Midnight dreamer

You will own one of smaller drawing from midnight dreamer series like above. First come, first choice so hurry to get exactly what you want. See more with this link. Look for size, 4.5" x 5.5".

(For owning bigger one, 7.5" x 9.5", see the $500, Sanctuary Maker section below) 

Plus a thank you note from Wyoming on a selection from my postcard collection and 3 greeting cards from the "One-Liner" collection.

$300 Wonderer

Have a night walk with me in cold winter. You will have one of the paintings above, 7.5" x 9.5" on paper, which conveys the feeling of a cold winter night walk. #Update!! Winter Tree had a taker! So, you will get "Full Moon Winter Night"

http://www.flickr.com/photos/7345606@N07/sets/72157637241028333/

Plus a thank you note from Wyoming on a selection from my postcard collection and 3 greeting cards from the "One-Liner" collection.


$350 Animal lover

I will send you one of the original pieces of the "One Liner Series" that was used to make the greeting cards. First come, first choice.

http://www.flickr.com/photos/7345606@N07/sets/72157621114663554/

Plus a thank you note from Wyoming on a selection from my postcard collection and 3 greeting cards from the "One-Liner" collection.

$380 Surveyor of the planet Jun


You will have a new one-of-a-kind acrylic painting of an imaginary landscape on 6" x 6" canvas in similar manner to the painting above. (Or you can have this one if you claim it first)
http://www.flickr.com/photos/7345606@N07/4857770963/

Plus a thank you note from Wyoming on a selection from my postcard collection and 3 greeting cards from the "One-Liner" collection.

$420 Botanist

You will be a proud owner of one of the original acrylic paintings of a close-up lotus flower!!

4.5" x 6.5", acrylic on paper with cherry color frame.

To see bigger images, click link here.

Plus a thank you note from Wyoming on a selection from my postcard collection and 3 greeting cards from the "One-Liner" collection.

$550 Sanctuary maker


I will send you one piece from the large "Midnight Dream" series. The large version of the "Midnight Dream" series, 7.5" x 9.5", is derived from the Buddhist prayer "May all sentient beings be happy and peaceful." First come, first choice.
They are in a 11" x 14" black wood frame.

Plus a thank you note from Wyoming on a selection from my postcard collection and 3 greeting cards from the "One-Liner" collection.

$800 Meditator


I will send you one of lotus series paintings on a 12" x 12" canvas. 

I have 5 paintings in this size and.You can seeing 4 of them above.  First come, first choice.

Plus a thank you note from Wyoming on a selection from my postcard collection and 3 greeting cards from the "One-Liner" collection.


$1,100 Friend of the planet Jun


You will receive the piece, "A Gold Fish Came to Smell a Lotus". It is acrylic on 4 wood panels, each panel is 6" w x 9" h for a total of 24" w x 9" h

See a larger photo on Flickr here.

Plus a thank you note from Wyoming on a selection from my postcard collection and 3 greeting cards from the "One-Liner" collection.

$1,800 Golden Circle of Planet Jun


You will be a proud owner of the "Everything is Changeable” You will also receive a thank you postcard from Wyoming and a set of 3 printed cards. Shipping outside of the US not included.

http://www.flickr.com/photos/7345606@N07/3648306286/


$2,500 Ambassador of the Planet Jun

Custom-made mandala in your location to be made by me, especially for you, using objects from the surrounding environment. I will instruct you in the practice of walking meditation using the mandala. Travel expenses, food, and lodging outside of New York City and materials that need to be purchased not included. 


More mandala installation images here

Plus a thank you note from Wyoming on a selection from my postcard collection and 5 greeting cards from the "One-Liner" collection.


$3,000 Senior Sage of the Planet Jun

"Om Mani Padme Hum" (Hail the jewel in the lotus)
Acrylic on canvas, 32" x 56" Along the stream of impermanence are layers of color, the Heart Sutra, lotus flowers blossoming, and the Zen Story of the 10 Bulls.  Shipping outside of the US not included. 

(link to the bigger image here)

Plus a thank you note from Wyoming on a selection from my postcard collection and 3 greeting cards from the "One-Liner" collection. You may have a kiss and hug too! 


In addition to the rewards listed above, if you see something you would like to have on my website or flickr page, please don't hesitate to ask. 

My art seeks beyond momentary pleasure. It aims to have an ongoing impact.

My art has been giving a positive effect to my audiences. I had received great compliments such as: " Your art changed my life!". What my art creations apart from others is that my piece is just not just for the temporary visual enjoyment, but makes audience realize the impermanence of life, and encourages them to live fully. Supporting my art creation is helping people to have peace and happiness in mind , one viewer at a time. 

Here is an example testimonial: 

testimonial by Nicki Lay

Also, here is a good interview I had about my art:

interview by lazy yogi 


Broke? You still can help me!!

You may not be able to make financial contribution. But you still can help me by spreading words out.

Please talk about my story with your friends and colleagues, post my campaign to your social media pages. 

Thank you very much for your support and help!! 

xoxo

Jun

story:
Will Mr. 'reluctant' Happy Feet dance? C'mon


                   “We shape our buildings and…our buildings shape us.”

                                              WINSTON CHURCHILL 

**Churchill said this after World War II, stressing how important rebuilding and restoring is to the economy of a street, a city, a nation. And of course, people.

OUR STORY:

See a stately magnificent building and PEOPLE’S heads snap around. What
secrets does it know? What musings can it tell? Did Al Capone hide any stash in
those glossy gilded vaults inside?  After all, he and his gang vacationed in southwest Michigan. Hey, the first time I saw it, MY head snapped around. Still does. Every time I look at this amazing historical bank building that sits on Main Street in Benton Harbor, Michigan. Huge circular corrugated pillars that seem to climb to the sky. Rectangular white terra cotta blocks fading but still gleaming from it, like it’s a twinkling star or something. And a roofline with pointy pediment, a clock resting just below its apex. Oh, but that clock way up there…without hands, not telling time right now… may be telling us that unless we come together at an apex,  maybe this amazing icon’s slipping away from us. A year from now? Perhaps two. A crumble and a peel at a time. And once it’s gone, it may be gone forever. We’re in DANGER of LOSING it! And want to do something about 92 WEST MAIN NOW!

So…before it takes its rightful place in a revitalizing area, an emerging “arts district,” before it becomes a center for award-winning live theater, event space, and non-for-profit photography gallery for students and local photographers to showcase their work, before it makes room on the lower level for retail and commerce, we believe – FAÇADE FIRST -- or it’s GONE! Please help SAVE this beloved piece of neo-classical architecture, in the heart of the city, from the wrecking ball! Stop 92 WEST MAIN’s face from cracking and peeling. Save it so we all can snap our heads around and gawk. Rejoice. And admire. Together.

SHERRY MILLER

We want to have fun while doing this, so…

Reach our goal perk: WE PROMISE TO DANCE IN FRONT OF THE FARMERS AND MERCHANTS BUILDING WHEN WE REACH OUR GOAL. CAN WE ENCOURAGE TOM TO DO IT? GO THROUGH WITH IT? SEE OUR ENTERTAINING VIDEO. WATCH FOR UPDATES. KEEP POSTED. WE’LL GET HIM TO DANCE YET.

 

Now for the really serious stuff...

About Saving the F and M

Time is ticking. Two, maybe even one year from now, it may be too late! But there’s still a chance to save the magnificent historical Farmers and Merchants Bank building. Beloved icon for more than 100 years, it sits stately at 92 West Main Street in Benton Harbor, Michigan. What an amazing place. It’s exciting! It’s revitalizing! Once threatening a ghost town, and after years of disrepair, the entire city’s in makeover mode, emerging as an arts district frequented by artists, dancers, musicians, photographers, and visitors. It’s bordered by St. Joseph, a thriving romantic tourist town right on Lake Michigan and a developing marina district on the St. Joseph River which boasts a brand new Jack Nicklaus Golf Course - Harbor Shores. It was proudly the site of the 73rd Senior PGA Golf Championship presented by KitchenAid in May 2012. And the Senior PGA will host the 75th in May, 2014. And good news. Recently, the PGA announced it will happen again in 2016 and 2018. But the F and M is falling behind all this progress. That’s important to know because restoration of the F and M will benefit the entire community and have a positive economic impact. We need your help to bring it back to life. And restore it to its original historic neo-classical beauty.

Its History

The F and M has a story to tell. It was established in 1888. By 1911, the owners (the O.B. Hipp name remains etched in stone East of the building to this day) gave it its present look: white terra cotta blocks, massive corrugated pillars, curlicue design at the roofline, and a pointy pediment housing a clock. Though long gone, the interior was finished in Italian marble and mahogany. Imagine the early 1900’s…A car hooded by a surrey-like canvas pulls up to 92 West Main. Women in big-brimmed hats and ankle-length dresses slide out of a speedster, maybe a roadster, followed by men dressed in top hats, taking a peek at their pocket watches. They enter the front doors talking, smiling. Perhaps they pause to admire the terra cotta blocks and architecture.

Disrepair; Fixing it

Nowadays, the F and M still enjoys admiring glances from passersby in Chevrolets, Fords, Chryslers, maybe a Honda or two. This building simply turns heads. But a closer look reveals pieces of terra cotta crumbling, pillars cracking and chipping, and the curlicues and pediment attracting birds keen on making this icon their home. Its bright face is fading. The owners did due diligence. They applied for grants but the money for those was scarce. They completed major repairs and renovations: a new roof drain system, stairway to the attic creating roof access, scraping, spackling, and painting walls, even shoveling and drying out the basement after a flood. And they installed netting to hold the terra cotta in place at the top of the pillars. “The upkeep has been a challenge,” says Tom Miller, co-owner and member of Smarts LLC (south of Main Arts). “But we keep on going.”

A Bigger Vision

Smarts has a bigger vision. As a writer, author, and award-winning playwright, Sherry Miller, a member, sees an “original works” theater showcasing award-winning children’s plays and experimental works; a creative place where talented writers will develop their scripts on the second floor. “We’d like to engage the local Benton Harbor High School for extracurricular classes/events as well as tap into local talent,” says Sherry. “And after initial development here, award-winning plays can find a full production home at the local high school’s state-of-the-art theater, or at colleges and universities.” The vision includes an event center, film studios, writer studios, classrooms, even retail and restaurant space. Renovated and ready right now is a hall for a non-for-profit photography gallery, a section of which will be dedicated to a
museum with pictorial history of Benton Harbor. Amazing people live and work in the Benton Harbor Arts District. Because of their dedication, businesses are breathing life back into the community. There’s WaterStreet Glassworks (a success story giving students and artists an opportunity to learn glassblowing), the renowned Citadel Dance and Music Center, fashion shops, resale stores, art galleries (e.g. the world renowned artist; Richard Hunt’s studio), antique shops, offices, workout studio, the Livery Brewery, and many restaurants including Babe’s, Bread Bar, Chatterbox, Euneek Bakery, The Ideal Place, The Library, Lark’s Barbeque, Piggin’ and Grinnin’, and the Phoenix Café. Cornerstone (chamber of commerce), housed in another bank building behind the F and M, continues to play a prominent role encouraging entrepreneurs and supporting this community. And the New Territory Arts Association resides here. It just keeps on growing.

 **NOTE: We’d like to see a culinary arts school here, too.

What Will It Take To ‘Save 92 West Main?’

People like you. Who believe in us. And our vision. And who believe in preserving history and architectural beauty. Our restoration project is divided into three (3) phases: fix and restore the façade, renovate space for theater and events, and repair and replace the elevator, electrical systems, and windows.  Estimates show it will total more than $150,000 to implement all three. A good start. So for right now, we are focusing on the first phase – the façade. Our goal? For the façade to be repaired for the next Senior PGA Championship presented by KitchenAid in May, 2014. And wouldn’t it be nice to surpass our goal allowing us to start the second phase at the same time? “When we first saw the F and M, we were mesmerized. Like those folks in 1911. Like those passersby today,” Sherry Miller offers. “A feeling of wanting to save it overwhelmed us. We originally invested in it to keep a gym from purchasing it. We just knew this building was more than sweaty workouts and treadmills. The F and M is meant to be admired like the treasure it once was.” We can do this. We can save 92 West Main.

Why Do We Need Money? And What for?

We, Smarts and Millers, extended our own resources to keep up with multiple repairs and tapped into our own personal finances. But a project of this magnitude requires so much more than what we’re able to give upfront. We’ve done estimates for these major renovations and they exceed $150,000. After deciding to concentrate on the first phase – the façade, we did a breakdown of costs for this campaign:

PHASE ONE:

Approximately,

$9,000 –

Marketing/Web/Media/Visual Media/Administrative. We will have some volunteers/interns available to help defray this cost.

$46,000 –

Masonry, historically restoring the façade. (estimate available)

$3,000 –

Work to ready the Hallway Walk of Fame (scrape, spackle, paint). Any additional monies are allotted to dividing the electricity into individual units. And replacing windows. A certain amount of labor donated by Tom Miller and volunteers.

_________

$58,000 – Total start-up required.

**We are absorbing other costs such as some promotion, some writing, and administrative. We have offers from volunteers and are thrilled.

 

Who Are We?

This IndieGoGo campaign was initiated by Smarts LLC, originally founded by Tom Miller, Sherry Miller, the Motts and R. Vance, and one silent partner (former school teacher) and supported by various arts affiliates locally and across the country, a big part by those associated with theater. Local BH entrepreneurs and community leaders also support this project. And have supported many of our grant applications and petitions. Smarts now is reduced to three (3) members.

Are Contributions Tax Deductible?

No. With the possibility of private investors in this building’s future and offering room for retail space as well as non-for-profit theater and non-for-profit Photography and pictorial museum wing, and because this project is not registered as a 501 ( c ) 3 non-for-profit and time restraints associated with doing that, contributions are not tax deductible. More details about the Farmers and Market Building and “Save 92 West Main” can be found on the website “Save 92 West Main.com” 
E-mail: save92westmain@gmail.com. Also find this campaign on Facebook: Facebook.com/BentonHarborRenaissance. Or type in: “Save 92 West Main.”

HELP US BY GETTING THE WORD OUT! PASS THIS ON!

Sherry Miller – writer, author, award-winning playwright, lover of the arts.

Tom Miller – Technical, painter, and engineer. And reluctant Mr. Happy Feet.

Julee Laurent - Media, pre-launch

Ugly Dog Media – Social Media, online campaign manager. South Bend, Indiana.

         photographer

         Monica Sherck - Graphic Designer

Doug Clark – videographer, Capture Me Films/Doug Clark Creative. Musician, song-writer, working on BH documentary.

Linda Dornseif – Actress, “Queenie” the Harlequin Clown, and at times, a volunteer.

A silent partner

story_txt:
Will Mr. 'reluctant' Happy Feet dance? C'mon
                   “We shape our buildings and…our buildings shape us.”
                                              WINSTON CHURCHILL  
**Churchill said this after World War II, stressing how important rebuilding and restoring is to the economy of a street, a city, a nation. And of course, people.
OUR STORY:
See a stately magnificent building and PEOPLE’S heads snap around. Whatsecrets does it know? What musings can it tell? Did Al Capone hide any stash inthose glossy gilded vaults inside?  After all, he and his gang vacationed in southwest Michigan. Hey, the first time I saw it, MY head snapped around. Still does. Every time I look at this amazing historical bank building that sits on Main Street in Benton Harbor, Michigan. Huge circular corrugated pillars that seem to climb to the sky. Rectangular white terra cotta blocks fading but still gleaming from it, like it’s a twinkling star or something. And a roofline with pointy pediment, a clock resting just below its apex. Oh, but that clock way up there…without hands, not telling time right now… may be telling us that unless we come together at an apex,  maybe this amazing icon’s slipping away from us. A year from now? Perhaps two. A crumble and a peel at a time. And once it’s gone, it may be gone forever. We’re in DANGER of LOSING it! And want to do something about 92 WEST MAIN NOW! 
So…before it takes its rightful place in a revitalizing area, an emerging “arts district,” before it becomes a center for award-winning live theater, event space, and non-for-profit photography gallery for students and local photographers to showcase their work, before it makes room on the lower level for retail and commerce, we believe – FAÇADE FIRST -- or it’s GONE! Please help SAVE this beloved piece of neo-classical architecture, in the heart of the city, from the wrecking ball! Stop 92 WEST MAIN’s face from cracking and peeling. Save it so we all can snap our heads around and gawk. Rejoice. And admire. Together.
SHERRY MILLER
We want to have fun while doing this, so…
Reach our goal perk: WE PROMISE TO DANCE IN FRONT OF THE FARMERS AND MERCHANTS BUILDING WHEN WE REACH OUR GOAL. CAN WE ENCOURAGE TOM TO DO IT? GO THROUGH WITH IT? SEE OUR ENTERTAINING VIDEO. WATCH FOR UPDATES. KEEP POSTED. WE’LL GET HIM TO DANCE YET.
 
Now for the really serious stuff...
About Saving the F and M
Time is ticking. Two, maybe even one year from now, it may be too late! But there’s still a chance to save the magnificent historical Farmers and Merchants Bank building. Beloved icon for more than 100 years, it sits stately at 92 West Main Street in Benton Harbor, Michigan. What an amazing place. It’s exciting! It’s revitalizing! Once threatening a ghost town, and after years of disrepair, the entire city’s in makeover mode, emerging as an arts district frequented by artists, dancers, musicians, photographers, and visitors. It’s bordered by St. Joseph, a thriving romantic tourist town right on Lake Michigan and a developing marina district on the St. Joseph River which boasts a brand new Jack Nicklaus Golf Course - Harbor Shores. It was proudly the site of the 73rd Senior PGA Golf Championship presented by KitchenAid in May 2012. And the Senior PGA will host the 75th in May, 2014. And good news. Recently, the PGA announced it will happen again in 2016 and 2018. But the F and M is falling behind all this progress. That’s important to know because restoration of the F and M will benefit the entire community and have a positive economic impact. We need your help to bring it back to life. And restore it to its original historic neo-classical beauty. 
Its History
The F and M has a story to tell. It was established in 1888. By 1911, the owners (the O.B. Hipp name remains etched in stone East of the building to this day) gave it its present look: white terra cotta blocks, massive corrugated pillars, curlicue design at the roofline, and a pointy pediment housing a clock. Though long gone, the interior was finished in Italian marble and mahogany. Imagine the early 1900’s…A car hooded by a surrey-like canvas pulls up to 92 West Main. Women in big-brimmed hats and ankle-length dresses slide out of a speedster, maybe a roadster, followed by men dressed in top hats, taking a peek at their pocket watches. They enter the front doors talking, smiling. Perhaps they pause to admire the terra cotta blocks and architecture.
Disrepair; Fixing it
Nowadays, the F and M still enjoys admiring glances from passersby in Chevrolets, Fords, Chryslers, maybe a Honda or two. This building simply turns heads. But a closer look reveals pieces of terra cotta crumbling, pillars cracking and chipping, and the curlicues and pediment attracting birds keen on making this icon their home. Its bright face is fading. The owners did due diligence. They applied for grants but the money for those was scarce. They completed major repairs and renovations: a new roof drain system, stairway to the attic creating roof access, scraping, spackling, and painting walls, even shoveling and drying out the basement after a flood. And they installed netting to hold the terra cotta in place at the top of the pillars. “The upkeep has been a challenge,” says Tom Miller, co-owner and member of Smarts LLC (south of Main Arts). “But we keep on going.”
A Bigger Vision
Smarts has a bigger vision. As a writer, author, and award-winning playwright, Sherry Miller, a member, sees an “original works” theater showcasing award-winning children’s plays and experimental works; a creative place where talented writers will develop their scripts on the second floor. “We’d like to engage the local Benton Harbor High School for extracurricular classes/events as well as tap into local talent,” says Sherry. “And after initial development here, award-winning plays can find a full production home at the local high school’s state-of-the-art theater, or at colleges and universities.” The vision includes an event center, film studios, writer studios, classrooms, even retail and restaurant space. Renovated and ready right now is a hall for a non-for-profit photography gallery, a section of which will be dedicated to amuseum with pictorial history of Benton Harbor. Amazing people live and work in the Benton Harbor Arts District. Because of their dedication, businesses are breathing life back into the community. There’s WaterStreet Glassworks (a success story giving students and artists an opportunity to learn glassblowing), the renowned Citadel Dance and Music Center, fashion shops, resale stores, art galleries (e.g. the world renowned artist; Richard Hunt’s studio), antique shops, offices, workout studio, the Livery Brewery, and many restaurants including Babe’s, Bread Bar, Chatterbox, Euneek Bakery, The Ideal Place, The Library, Lark’s Barbeque, Piggin’ and Grinnin’, and the Phoenix Café. Cornerstone (chamber of commerce), housed in another bank building behind the F and M, continues to play a prominent role encouraging entrepreneurs and supporting this community. And the New Territory Arts Association resides here. It just keeps on growing.
 **NOTE: We’d like to see a culinary arts school here, too.
What Will It Take To ‘Save 92 West Main?’
People like you. Who believe in us. And our vision. And who believe in preserving history and architectural beauty. Our restoration project is divided into three (3) phases: fix and restore the façade, renovate space for theater and events, and repair and replace the elevator, electrical systems, and windows.  Estimates show it will total more than $150,000 to implement all three. A good start. So for right now, we are focusing on the first phase – the façade. Our goal? For the façade to be repaired for the next Senior PGA Championship presented by KitchenAid in May, 2014. And wouldn’t it be nice to surpass our goal allowing us to start the second phase at the same time? “When we first saw the F and M, we were mesmerized. Like those folks in 1911. Like those passersby today,” Sherry Miller offers. “A feeling of wanting to save it overwhelmed us. We originally invested in it to keep a gym from purchasing it. We just knew this building was more than sweaty workouts and treadmills. The F and M is meant to be admired like the treasure it once was.” We can do this. We can save 92 West Main.
Why Do We Need Money? And What for?
We, Smarts and Millers, extended our own resources to keep up with multiple repairs and tapped into our own personal finances. But a project of this magnitude requires so much more than what we’re able to give upfront. We’ve done estimates for these major renovations and they exceed $150,000. After deciding to concentrate on the first phase – the façade, we did a breakdown of costs for this campaign:
PHASE ONE:
Approximately, 
$9,000 – 
Marketing/Web/Media/Visual Media/Administrative. We will have some volunteers/interns available to help defray this cost. 
$46,000 –
Masonry, historically restoring the façade. (estimate available)
$3,000 –
Work to ready the Hallway Walk of Fame (scrape, spackle, paint). Any additional monies are allotted to dividing the electricity into individual units. And replacing windows. A certain amount of labor donated by Tom Miller and volunteers.
_________
$58,000 – Total start-up required.
**We are absorbing other costs such as some promotion, some writing, and administrative. We have offers from volunteers and are thrilled.
 
Who Are We?
This IndieGoGo campaign was initiated by Smarts LLC, originally founded by Tom Miller, Sherry Miller, the Motts and R. Vance, and one silent partner (former school teacher) and supported by various arts affiliates locally and across the country, a big part by those associated with theater. Local BH entrepreneurs and community leaders also support this project. And have supported many of our grant applications and petitions. Smarts now is reduced to three (3) members.
Are Contributions Tax Deductible?
No. With the possibility of private investors in this building’s future and offering room for retail space as well as non-for-profit theater and non-for-profit Photography and pictorial museum wing, and because this project is not registered as a 501 ( c ) 3 non-for-profit and time restraints associated with doing that, contributions are not tax deductible. story:
Greetings,

My name is Doug and I have been in the art and picture framing business for 22 years. During this time I have enjoyed selling framed art and creating custom personal memories for thousands of customers.

 

           

Early in my career I was able to design and build stores for a chain of art and framing stores called Off the Wall. These stores were located in regional malls around the country and enjoyed much success in the 80's-90's.

                               

In the late 90's I left retail to focus my talents in wholesale and help start electric-art-gallery.com

                        


These electrically powered lighted artworks made it to almost every mall in America and were sold through stores such as Deck the Walls, Prints Plus as well as markets abroad.

Currently I work for a big box retailer were I have been trying to break into upper management to no avail.

Over the years I have been acquiring equipment piece by piece in hopes of someday opening my own business. Now I have almost everything I need to do so. A supportive wife and family along with 10K worth of equipment and a great cutting edge idea!

Picture Framing in Virtual Reality

(The future of framing)

Technology today has made it possible to demonstrate different framing and matting possibilities through the use of computers and custom visualization software. This technique is in use in the big box stores as well as other frame shops across the country. Virtual-Framing takes this idea to the next level. By incorporating technologies available I can do in home design consultations using a laptop and an HD LED projector. "Want to see what this masterpiece would look like over your couch?" POW! There it is in actual size right where you intend on hanging it in full HD! This gives the customer full confidence that the design and color combinations will work with their decor and color schemes.

I only need a few things to make this a reality.

  • Design software which is available for license.
  • A 6000 lumens HD LED Projector
  • HD video compatible laptop
  • Website design
As I mentioned I have all the framing equipment already. I only need help on the technology side. I have registered virtual-framing.com and have started designing a website to support the business. A version of the design software will be available on the website for customers to design their own framing ideas. This will be a great way to get clients excited about scheduling an in home consult where they can view their creation in virtual reality without spending a dollar!

Living in the San Francisco Bay area I see huge potential for this business. Marketing through social media and word of mouth will keep me busy once I get a few jobs under my belt. Partnering with local artists and businesses will help with our exposure.

A newly framed picture in someone's home is always a talking point when people come to visit. What better advertising that a happy customer telling their friends and family about the business that comes to your house and can show you what the finished product will look like in Virtual Reality!

Your help in making this dream a reality is thoroughly appreciated.
