story:
THANK YOU EVERYONE! We appreciate your kind words, likes, shares, contributions, and support! You've encouraged us so much! We will keep you posted on all of our upcoming endeavors.

Stay connected through our website www.gmossdesign.com, facebook.com/gmossdesign, and twitter.com/gmossdesign.

Hi, my name is George Moss. I've been drawing since the age of six years old. I've had the opportunity to create graphic designs, fashion tech designs, commissioned illustrations, exhibit my art in groups and solo shows in the Miami, Ft. Lauderdale, and the Palm Beach, Florida areas. The Story was created to encourage the young and older generation to seek their purpose and use their talents to help their communities.  

Read the SYNOPSIS HERE:

 “THE CHRONICLES OF ANN & LO”.  In the summer of 2099, the Magic City, an area of peace and tranquility, was violently taken over by a gas bomb from the Evil Shadow Regimen. In ancient times this Regimen used mind control, fear, and extreme violence to conquer empires. A few blocks away, two teens Ann and her little brother Lo, witness the bombing, and saw their close friend abducted. THEIR ONLY HOPE IS TO TEAM UP WITH TWO MYSTERIOUS OUTSIDERS TO RESCUE THEIR FRIEND AND TAKE BACK THEIR NEIGHBORHOOD. CAN THEY SAVE THE CITY OR WILL THEY BECOME MIND-CONTROLLED SLAVES THEMSELVES?

Any funds that we collect over our goal will go towards these additional goals:

1) The listed costs will pay for the Artist space rental and traveling expenses (food, gas, and lodging).

    • Daytona Beach Comic Convention 2014 ($465)

    • PalmCon 2014 ($350)

    • Animate Miami 2015 ($425)

    • Megacon 2015 ($1400)

2) The Creation of the "Bam" T-shirt. Design Production Cost: $690

3) Cut and Sewing Production of 12 new Prototype Gmoss clothing styles in our Line to show/sell to store buyers at apparel/licensing trade show. Funds will pay for cutting and sewing of the styles, booth space rental, travel expenses, Product and Display shipping, and lodging. Production and Licensing Trade Show 2014 or 2015 Total Cost: $10,500


You can SHARE this campaign with your friends and family. Even if you cannot financially contribute, you can still HELP BY SPREADING THE WORD about our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, texting or by emailing your friends.

CHECK OUT OUR GREAT PERKS BELOW!

$5 Perk: Ann & Lo Volume 2 Wallpaper Bundle for Desktop/Laptop, Tablet, and Cell Phone.

$15 Perk: Ann and Lo Character Cards

$20 Perk: Ann and Mo Turntable Posters

$30 Perk: The Anthem Tee and Poster


$35 Perk: The Chronicles of Ann and Lo Volume 1 and The Anthem Poster


$40 Perk: One Custom Gmoss Phone Case Limited Edition - Only 50 available.  Phone Options: iPhone 4/4s & 5/5s Cases or Galaxy S3/S4 Cases.


$50 Perk: 24"x36" "The Crew In Danger" Glossy Poster Print Art from The Chronicles of Ann & Lo Volume 2. Signed By Gmoss.


$75 Perk: Snapback Cap (Trucker Hat), Custom Beanie, The Anthem Poster, The The Faithful Servant Poster, and Anthem Lanyard.



$100 Perk: Original Pencil Drawn Character Art from The Chronicles of Ann and Lo Volume 1 (Five Character Drawings Available - 1 of 5 for each person)

$200 Perk: 16"x20" Digital Art Frame - "Agent Jeff Kross" Head DEA Agent from The Chronicles of Ann and Lo Volume 1


$200 Perk: "African Americana”  Mixed Media Art - Watercolor, Acrylic, Pencil 11”x14” Art printed on heavy card stock.


$200 Perk: 16"x20" Digital Art Frame - "Teaching the Next Generation" from The Chronicles of Ann and Lo Volume 1



$250 Perk: 16"x20" Digital Art Frame - "Enter Bamboozle", Bam Trucker, and more...




$300 Perk: Lady Day - Pencil Art

Approximate size Original art (11x14)  with 20 x 24 Dark Wood Frame.


$300 Perk: 16"x20"x1 1/2" Canvas Digital Art  - "Can't See". Plus Bam Trucker Hat (see above picture)


$300 Perk: Swing Jazz Pencil Illustration – Original Art

11x14 Artwork Matted and Frame


$300 Perk: 16"x20"x1 1/2" Canvas Digital Art  - "Ann's Power". Plus The Anthem Lanyard.


$500 Perk: Original Art 18"x24" Canvas Pencil and Acrylic - "Freedom"

$700 Perk: Special Guest of Gmoss at one of his Comic Book Events and more!!! Includes: Custom Tee, The Anthem Lanyard, and one pass to the event of artist's selection. One copy of Volume 1 and 2 of The Chronicles of Ann and Lo. One CD copy of his Product Development Workshop containing product development information and clothing/accessories templates. One hour fashion consultation discussing your own product line. The guest must be able to make their own travel arrangements to the comic book event.

For a design that you would like to have made, please contact me at gmossdesign.com

Plus The Anthem Lanyard.$500 Perk: Original Art 18"x24" Canvas Pencil and Acrylic - "Freedom"$700 Perk: Special Guest of Gmoss at one of his Comic Book Events and more!!! Includes: Custom Tee, The Anthem Lanyard, and one pass to the event of artist's selection. One copy of Volume 1 and 2 of The Chronicles of Ann and Lo. One CD copy of his Product Development Workshop containing product development information and clothing/accessories templates. One hour fashion consultation discussing your own product line. The guest must be able to make their own travel arrangements to the comic book event.For a design that you would like to have made, please contact me at gmossdesign.com

story:
Hi, I’m Chris (playa name “Keys”), a 13 year burner who has decided I want my burn this year to be more interactive by helping people unable to attend Burning Man, vicariously experience it, as well as helping those that are attending, have an even more amazing experience!

     Actually, I’m taking a huge risk. In keeping with the principle of radical self-reliance I have decided not to purchase a ticket and instead decided to raise any and all money for ticket/food/gas by being your playa representative and, consequently, if I don’t raise the money, then perhaps this year I am not meant to be on the Playa.

     Since my first burn in 2000 I have participated in many different ways: I have created fallout shelters and crashed ship dance clubs, given away root beer floats and playful whippings, hosted artists for dinner and help set up major theme camps. I’ve experienced just about every life event you can think of on the playa, including birthday parties, engagements and weddings.  I’ve even placed the ashes of two fellow campmates in the Temple, one being one of my original four campmates from my very first year.

     This year I want to give back and use my burner knowledge and experience to help others and earn my way back. I have created perks that will allow both those on and off the playa an opportunity to enhance their experience. For those on playa, I offer my knowledge, abilities and resources. For those off playa, I offer the opportunity to vicariously experience the playa with me as your avatar. For those that have never even been, maybe you just want a piece of Burning Man and a better understanding of what this whole crazy event is all about and hopefully I can help with that desire.

     Keys (aka Chris)

story:
Hi, my name is Marcus.
I'm an artist/designer/musician living in Southern California.
My button maker was stolen a couple years ago. I miss it dearly. Here's the story:

When I was 13 years old I began going to local punk shows. Apart from the memories, my favourite thing to take with me from these gatherings were 1" buttons (aka: pinkbacks). I would pin them on my jacket, my schoolbag, my jeans, or just leave them scattered about my house. As a gift when I was 17 my parents purchased me a 1" button machine. This was a dream! I couldn't be stopped! I made them for my friend's bands, as gifts, mementos for family members, even button making parties! The list goes on and on.

A couple years back a 'friend' asked if he could borrow my button machine. This was no problem for me, as it was common for me to loan it out. What's the point of having anything if it can't be shared, right?

 

I left town for a couple weeks, and when I returned I had a difficult time getting ahold of my friend who had borrowed the machine. I was then informed that he had the intentions of moving across the country. He left - I can only assume with my button machine and I haven't heard from him since. 3 years of friendship toss asunder over a button machine? It seems surreal, I know...

Aaaannyway...I miss it. I want a new one. I'd love your help!

The button maker itsself isn't that expensive. Indiegogo requires you to have a minimum of $500, but if we raise more money I may be able to get a better quality one, or maybe be able to make differnet size buttons, or maybe even a new printer so I don't have to make my prints at kinko's!

story:
Artist Linda Carmella Sibio and Bezerk Productions have launched this Indiegogo fundraising campaign to support Sibio’s ambitious new body of work, “Economics of Suffering.”   Sibio, who has been indisposed due to serious (and costly) illness since 2008, made a remarkable recovery during the past year and has returned to working on her artwork full-time.  Due to her illness, funds have been tight, so Sibio is turning to supporters and art enthusiasts to help her bring her new work into the world. 

Economics of Suffering

Economics of Suffering is an artistic exploration into the psychological effects of a world economy that is collapsing and creating a fertile bed for individual pain and suffering. The images explore issues such as starvation, AIDS, blue-collar workers, healthcare, torture and genocide.

The  multimedia project includes live performance, 36 epic paintings, sound, video, and two very strange closets.  The full-length performance piece is Sibio's first since 2006.  She will also create a haunting soundtrack using a vocal distortion machine.  Blake Matthew Brousseau will use found images, created images and his unique blend of short clips with emotionally impacting imagery.

What We Need

$3000 will pay for the supplies needed to launch this epic masterpiece. 

Contributions will fund the painting supply costs for dozens of Linda Carmella Sibio works on paper and other project elements.  Specifically, funds will be used to purchase paint, archival paper, gold leaf, framing, and video production services. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word to your people.  Every little bit helps!!  No contribution is too small.  Thank you!! <3

Art in madness.



Linda Carmella Sibio's Artist Statement

Since 1985, I have worked in various media including painting, installation and performance art. In 1985, I assisted in starting The Los Angeles Poverty Department (a homeless performance art troupe on skid row in Los Angeles, CA).  During this year I started working with the homeless mentally ill which affected my work for the next 20 years.

I am very much interested in the fringe of society and how that affects culture as a whole. I have combined strong social issues such as homelessness, mental illness, suicide, mass murder, gangs, drug addiction and prostitution with progressive elements in design and form thus creating my own sub-culture language. Madness has been a dominant theme in my work having been influenced by my own diagnosis as schizophrenic and my mother’s incarceration in mental hospitals for 15 years during my childhood.

My philosophy was developed through a combination of personal experience and intellectual pursuits. My perceptions were influenced by Marcel Duchamp’s book “The Bride Stripped Bare by the Bachelor’s Even,” Foucault’s “Madness and Civilization”, “Theater and It’s Double” by Antonin Artaud and “Anti-Oedipus” by Deleuze and Gautier. Visually in design my work was developed from looking at medieval manuscript paintings, ancient ruins, Mayan hieroglyphs, Soutine, Hieronymous Bosch, and Van Gogh.

Although my visual art training stems from an academic background I have replaced these design techniques with that from my research into the perceptions of the insane. I have taken “symptoms” of insanity and transposed them into techniques for making experimental art. These methods include fragmentation, interrupters, non-linear time sequencing, multiple layers of images and stories, dismemberment, psychological torture, broadcasting, delusions and hallucinations. These techniques have lead to work where there are layers and layers of images leading to an epic effect.

Through teaching mentally disabled persons I create a microcosm or a sub-culture against which the voice of social consciousness, politics, philosophy and visual art can be explored. In this exploration I recognized the need to integrate that, which is mad into my core thinking. It is through this that I am able to function in the context of a fragmented world.

My philosophical stance includes the modern day ostracizing of the insane from a productive society. In ancient times the insane were looked to for insights and guidance, today they clean dishes and bus tables. We can learn a lot about our society and culture by how the mad are treated. As we dispose of human beings so then we go toward a disposable culture.

The fragmented thinking of the schizophrenic is actually a window into the placement of our culture. We are living in a deconstructed world no longer thinking linear thoughts. Our perceptions are continually interrupted by television, Internet, video surveillance, the media – we no longer have a single thought. We think in a multi-layered complex pattern. In order for our culture to go forward the darkness of the dismembered body needs to come into the light. We need to fragment in order to become whole again.

story:
Who we are:

A New Seed NYC (ANSNYC) is a project dedicated to exposing deserving students to New York City's art community while helping them explore possible career paths with artistic professionals as mentors.

ANSNYC gives creative individuals the chance to find a passion regardless of their ability to pay for access to opportunity.

The need:

NYC is filled with eager students interested in their city’s artistic community. Unfortunately, it can be difficult finding resources to help them explore those interests.

Well, what if these students had those resources? That’s where we come in...

Our mission:

Our mission is to foster the development of New York City’s young arts students from under-served communities.

We provide high school to college aged students the opportunity to:

  • interact and learn from professionals in various fields through mentoring programs and community workshops.
  • attend performances and events in New York City through donations and sponsored tickets.
  • be exposed to career positions beyond the artists and performers themselves.
  • and through our website, stay connected with other creative students and professionals, forming a local community of motivated minds.


You’re invited to learn more about this project through our website…

www.ANewSeed.com

Just As Importantly- Spread the word! Share our Indiegogo campaign and Facebook page with friends, colleagues and family.

Follow us and stay connected:

  • Facebook https://www.facebook.com/ANewSeedNYC
  • Twitter – @ANewSeed

Please feel free to contact us by email with any inquiries at info@ANewSeed.com

We hope to build a program to help nourish arts education in our community.

With a little support, we can make a big impact on these student’s futures, so please get involved today and help us bring Our City’s Art to Our City’s Youth!

story:
Since 2008 I have been performing magic shows for libraries, nursing homes, assisted living facilities, school groups, scout groups, birthday parties, fairs, festivals and more.  I have the basic skills, props and equipment necessary to present a good magic show, and am ready to take my magic to the next level.  For that, I need advanced instruction.

The Master Class
Magician Jeff McBride has created the Magic and Mystery School which offers Master Classes for magicians.  During the Master Class students:

  • Receive detailed feedback on their routines from professional magicians.
  • Attend classes on the performance and business of magic.
  • Learn about specific magic techniques in small groups.
  • Study magic theory and philosophy.
  • Get personal instruction from the legends of magic.

Free Magic Shows for Seniors
Nursing homes are in need of quality entertainment for their residents, but a magic show doesn’t only provide entertainment.  It has been demonstrated that watching and participating in a magic performance can benefit the cognitive skills of persons with various debilitating mental ailments, including Alzheimer’s disease.

As a way to give back, if I meet my fundraising goal I will perform five magic shows – free of charge, to various nursing homes and assisted living facilities in the northeast Wisconsin area.

Use of Contributions
By contributing to my campaign, you can help me make my dream of attending the Master Class come true, have the satisfaction of knowing that you helped many elderly people, and learn some cool magic tricks, too!

If I meet my fundraising goal, this is how the $3,000 will be distributed:

  • $1,500 – Class tuition
  •    $500 – Air fare
  •    $500 – Hotel
  •    $300 – Car rental
  •    $200 – Meals

story:
Hello Friends! My name's Neil and I am a digital illustrator and caricature artist. I use some important equipment everyday to earn my living and provide for my family. Of those tools, my digital tablet monitor and my caricature easel are breaking!

The most pressing issue for me in the Cintiq. I use a Wacom Cintiq 21UX tablet monitor that I can directly draw on the screen and see the result under the pen. I’ve gained a lot of skill in digital drawing because of the Cintiq and it allows me to work faster, more efficient, and get better quality results. It is a key element in my everyday work.

 

As you can see from the pictures, my Cintiq is in major need of repairs. To have it fixed I will need to mail this heavy piece of equipment out to California. Shipping alone could cost over $100.

Without your help, we would need to commit a lot of money we don’t have yet and our progress in our goals for moving to a new home would be hurt greatly. Any level of monetary support would be immensely appreciated. Check out the perks for donating certain amounts!

If I'm able to raise over $500 (or if repairs manage to cost less.) I will use the extra money to replace the easel I use for caricatures which is on it's last legs as well.

story:
What is Unspoken?

Unspoken is a new play that explores the most essential relationship - the relationship between human beings and language - through music, spoken word, storytelling. movement and audience interaction.


How does language impact our individual and community identities? How can we communicate when we can't trust language? Even when two people speak the same language, does that mean they can truly communicate?


Who are we?

Closer Look is a multi arts collective that seeks to better understand the world around us through art. Amelia, Fareed and Ariel, three friends who met while working at a regional theater in Washington, DC, are the creative team for this piece. These three muskateers discovered their shared aesthetic and passion for socially conscious art and set out to create a brand new piece for the 2015 Atlas INTERSECTIONS Festival.

They have then gathered together a rock-star group of designers, performers, and writers who are all donating their time and talent to make this play possible.

What we need & What you get!

To make our brand new play the best it can we be, we need your help covering some basic costs.Here’s what we’ll need -

  • A Set

  • Props

  • Costumes

  • Programs

  • (and if there’s anything left over, we’ll even get to compensate the many artists who are working for free!)

If you help us transform our ideas from the page to the stage we’ll show you our thanks with some super cool prizes!

For $5 You’ll get a shout out on Twitter

For $10 You’ll get a shout out on Twitter and in the program

For $20 You’ll get all of the above and a signed postcard by the creative team

For $50 You’ll get all of the above and a CD of the original soundtrack of Unspoken

The Impact

  • You’d be bringing a brand new play to life!

  • You’d be funding starving artists looking to make an impact in their world.

  • You’d be helping to facilitate a conversation about one of our most basic human capacities - language.

  • You’d be backing a play that will be affordable for all audiences to attend.

Risks & Challenges

This is Closer Look’s first foray into play-making, and we are nervous but excited! The play has already been accepted into the Atlas INTERSECTIONS Festival for March 2015.

IT WILL BE HAPPENING!

If we’re not able to raise the entirety of our goal, we will not be able to pay the many talented and generous artists who are donating their skills to make this play wonderful.

Other Ways You Can Help

Theater is all about collaboration, and we are seeking to expand our network through not just your donations, but your insights and ideas.

We are using Twitter as a platform to crowdsource the answers to questions like -

What is your favorite word?

What words are hard to say?

Follow us at @UnspokenPlay and be a part of the conversation!


Also feel free to pass the information along to your friends and neighbors who may be interested in supporting new art.


And finally - please come see our play!

Unspoken

Friday, March 6, 2015

8:30pm

Atlas Performing Arts Center

Lab 1

story:
Short Summary

Right from the start let me tell you that I DO NOT NEED $500 but a mere $140 to cover the costs for this. 

Indigogo's minimum funding goal just happens to be $500 and that is a lot more than I need.

===

My name is Alex Austin and my wife and I just moved to Los Angeles from NYC shortly after going through years dealing with immigration to get me over from Europe. 

While my wife has a wonderful job here I am struggling to find work to support us, so I reach out to you to help me make a job where I can't find one at the moment.

Because of my accent I'm frequently approached and encouraged to do voice over work. I love recording speeches for my friends in my spare time. To do this properly I want to upgrade to this:

What I Need

A YETI Blue microphone, currently on sale for $129 and a pop shield (about $7).
As mentioned before, I need significantly less than $500 to achieve this.


Right now I am recording on my phone with a tiny headset. This is good and fine for a laugh with my friends, but nothing I can produce something more serious with. 

If I don't reach your entire goal, I will save it up to get it at an appropriate time.

What You Get

Whether it's a personalized voice mail message, an intro or ad read for your podcast or a quaint hand written letter that can evolve into becoming penpals, look to the right for more details!

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge with these campaigns is getting the perks to you. 
Once you donate, make sure to leave your email/Twitter/etc. so I can contact you!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, I totally understand. Maybe let someone else know by sharing it on Twitter, Facebook or whatnot?
story_txt:
Short Summary Right from the start let me tell you that I DO NOT NEED $500 but a mere $140 to cover the costs for this. 
Indigogo's minimum funding goal just happens to be $500 and that is a lot more than I need.
===
My name is Alex Austin and my wife and I just moved to Los Angeles from NYC shortly after going through years dealing with immigration to get me over from Europe. 
While my wife has a wonderful job here I am struggling to find work to support us, so I reach out to you to help me make a job where I can't find one at the moment.
Because of my accent I'm frequently approached and encouraged to do voice over work. I love recording speeches for my friends in my spare time. To do this properly I want to upgrade to this:   What I Need

A YETI Blue microphone, currently on sale for $129 and a pop shield (about $7).

As mentioned before, I need significantly less than $500 to achieve this.

Right now I am recording on my phone with a tiny headset. This is good and fine for a laugh with my friends, but nothing I can produce something more serious with. 
If I don't reach your entire goal, I will save it up to get it at an appropriate time.

What You GetWhether it's a personalized voice mail message, an intro or ad read for your podcast or a quaint hand written letter that can evolve into becoming penpals, look to the right for more details!

    Risks & Challenges  The biggest challenge with these campaigns is getting the perks to you. Once you donate, make sure to leave your email/Twitter/etc. so I can contact you!   Other Ways You Can Help If you can't contribute, I totally understand. Maybe let someone else know by sharing it on Twitter, Facebook or whatnot?

story:
Why are we on Indiegogo?

This limited edition printing project aim to get funding for a A0/A1 size ink jet printer for our workshop. We currently outsource all our printing to various partners but would like to advance to the next step in our business. Our intend is to brighten the day of everyone who is looking at our printed art pieces.


What are we doing?

First and foremost we have sold our prints in limited runs to companies and hotels to be displayed in open spaces and rooms. With the capability of running in-house printed editions we can finally make our prints available the broader public market in the next months to come.

Our designs and motives are modern abstract, consist largely of colorful curves and patterns. We have a new, differently styled, collection of coming up in June that we will aim to print in 3 different sizes on various materials .


Our Style...

Our ambition has always been to create art that you can loose your thoughts and sights in, with the ability to give colorful accents to otherwise plain areas.

Every print is hand-numbered from one to five and stamped from the back. All our posters are limited to 5 prints - with a few exceptions of prints that we only print 3 times.

We are currently printing A0, A1 and A3 on several different mediums but like to increase the variety of mediums and sizes. We have experimented with some very large prints in the past, but currently have put that on hold due to the high cost.

We need you!

The scope of this project is to get backers who buy 1, 2 or more prints so we can raise enough funds to buy our own large format printer.

Risks and challenges

The risks and challenges of this project are low since much of the work has already been done. We already work in close cooperation with a local printing company who will ensure that all backers will receive their perks on time, just in case we can not get to our campaign goal.

Minor color variations may occur since your screen shows colors slightly different that the actual print.

For the backers of you who back us with "the big one!" Perk, you'll be receiving a unique print of your choice including the high-res digital files and the copyrights for the artwork.

Amazing!!

story:
Short Summary          

New Amsterdam was a 17th-century Dutch settlement established at the southern tip of Manhattan Island, which served as the seat of the colonial government in New Netherland. New Amsterdam was renamed New York on September 8, 1664.

I am Richard Koek, A Dutch-American born in The Netherlands and raised by an Argentinian mother. I am a New Yorker. I decided to exchange my native Old-Amsterdam for New York City. For a few years I have been capturing this wonderful city with a new perspective. Click here to see a preview of some of the work..


When Tattoo star David Sena from SENA SPACE asked me to show my street work in his gallery. I realized that creating stories is the core of my work and the central characteristic of being a being human. People bring stories to David, so he can make a meaningful tattoo image, I will show you my images, which hopefully inspires you to create your stories. A perfect match!
 

Julia Gruen, executive Director of the Keith Haring Foundation, New York City, and Erik van Ginkel, Managing Director of the Rijksmuseum, Amsterdam, The Netherlands, have selected the content for this show. I will exhibit their exciting narrative by means of my images. 

The show opens July 14, 2016 6-9 PM and will run until September 1. It is my first solo show and the start of more ventures with this library of images. (Good news will follow soon). With your help you receive rewards that make you show your love for NYC, to your friends.  Please help me with the final stretch and most likely your chance for a sweet investment as well.

FIRST: Come to the show, bring your friends

Share the love. Show your love by just coming to the opening and see the pictures for real. Like shakespeare said: "A screen, is a screen, is a screen, but your presence is real." ;-)I would be grateful to give you a personal hug., to hear your story. All is good. SENA SPACE is located on 229 Center Street. Click here to go to Google Maps.

What is needed

I have had wonderful support from Dutch Culture USA (Kingdom of The Netherlands), Hand Baldachin & Amburgey, LLP and Short Stay Citizens. I need for the last stretch your support. They have covered over half of my expenses. What is needed is additional funding for

  1. printing
  2. the decoration of a complete wall with 1 image
  3. lettering on the window
  4. the opening party, with entertainment

Total needed is an additional $3,000.

The perks are wonderful

Show your love with something real! Get that set of NEW AMSTERDAM postcards including special USPS approved NEW AMSTERDAM stamps! (a national or international postage set).


No need to go to the post office. Write, stamp and mail. Literally sharing your love for NYC.

Limited edition prints available: a RED REWARD and a BLUE REWARD.

And for those who want to get something REALLY special: YOUR NAME credited on the store window for the duration of the show. Joining the logo of The Kingdom of The Netherlands. I mean when will you get that opportunity again?! You will receive a photo of the store window.

SPECIAL : THE BLACK REWARD ! (see the perk: Magnolia)
what is NYC without that edge? See for more details the perk on the right.

 

 

This show is supported as part of the Dutch Culture USA program of the Consulate General of The Netherlands in New York. http://www.dutchcultureusa.com/

story:
Hi!


My name is Barbara. I'm the founder of Cadeauté Bold Designs and the designer behind Cadeauté's creations. 

In 2006 I started to dream of learning Pottery. I didn't know anything about it back then, but I knew that I wanted to put my hands in the clay on a wheel and create.

The opportunity to learn Pottery came in January 2013. Four courses later, my love for it has grown stronger, as well as my desire to have a pottery studio at home and share that passion through Cadeauté.

"Barbara Lima has a rare combination of qualities: she is both attentive to details of design and skilled in meticulously executing those designs. I always look forward to seeing her next piece, knowing that it will be simply and honestly beautiful." Olaf de Winter (Director of Ceramics at the Visual Arts Centre, teacher, ceramicist)
Having a pottery studio at home will allow me to explore my creative process more frequently and more consistently, to integrate pottery to my other artistic projects at Cadeauté and fulfill the orders that I have been receiving.

Your support will help me pay for a Shimpo VL-Whisper wheel and a small Cone Art kiln (to fire my pieces), as well as a shelving system that will be used to place my pieces as I make them and a work table for wedging (working the clay). Any extra money raised will be used to buy clay and specialized pottery tools.
 
In appreciation for your help, I'll be offering different categories of rewards at your choice.

Cups and Mugs


Bowls 


 

Chip 'n' Dip


Cadeauté Florescência pillow case and eye pillow


Cadeauté Florescência Notebook Set


Cadeauté Geometric Urge art print 


All pieces will be handmade by me. Other than one of the rewards that I'm offering, you will also receive my deepest gratitude and potentially a hug, in case you live close by! =]


Thank you so much for your support!!

Love,
Barbara

story:
Hi, my name is Naomi VanDoren. I am the creator of a collection of Siamese art prints and the illustrator of my very first cat calendar. This calendar features 12 new cats never before published. I would greatly appreciate your support in getting it to press because without you it will never be printed.

This calendar is an Indiegogo online exclusive. After this event it will not be available for purchase online!

The calendar interior has a minimal, clean design. I have designed each month's artwork to compliment the season. The dimensions are 135mm x 297mm (or 5.3 x 11.7 inches) and printed on a matte white 100lb cover card stock. The top is wire bound and has a wire 'o hanger hook for easy hanging. I am currently finalizing the print details with two printers.

All of the funds raised will go into printing the calendar, cards and prints, packaging and shipping costs, and Indiegogo's fees. The extra printed material will be sold at events so this is your only time to get the calendar online!

I have completed the drawings and am cleaning them up for print. I will update here as they are ready. Please note that the postcards and A4 prints will not have the month printed on them!

I have been illustrating our two cats since 2012. We adopted them both and they have become an important part of our little family. Along with drawing cats I also paint fantasy art. You can read more about me and see my work here.

Shipping

Yes! The calendar will ship internationally. Shipping costs have been included.

Risks & Challenges

I have a background in graphic design and am familiar with the printing process. However, as with any printed project, there could be delays in shipping from the printer to my location. That is partly why I have chosen to launch this project now and not closer to the new year.

This is my first crowdfunding campaign. I am doing all that I can to prepare in advance but I know there are things that one simply cannot prepare for. I look forward to doing more projects with you in the future!

Other Ways You Can Help

I know that a cat calendar isn't for everyone. But chances are you know someone that would love one. Please share this project and spread the word!
Thank-you so much!


I want to thank Peter Mohrbacher and Sam Flegal and those who are a part of the One Fantastic Week group for the encouragement to get out there and try this!

story:
Be A Part Of An AMAZING Biblical Experience!

If you believe in the Bible, then you've seen perhaps some of the world's greatest artwork portraying religious scenes.  You can be part of strengthening the cause of Christ and help change lives for the good!  With your support, you’ll help to establish a vision of world-class "Bible in Art Galleries" that take guests on a pictorial journey through the great stories of the Bible.

The curators are planning to build the inspiring “Bible in Art Galleries” in multiple locations across the nation.  The first "Bible in Art Galleries" will be established in Salt Lake City, UT with additional locations planned for Branson, MO, Nashville, TN, Washington DC, and many others!

Our Galleries are biblically based and will present reproductions of hundreds of breathtaking biblical art created by the old masters to the contemporaries of today.

Inspiring!  Uplifting!  Amazing!

Featured paintings will be organized and displayed in 10 biblically themed galleries.  Beyond that, themed specialty Galleries will be featuring breathtaking artistic works that depict God and Country, and Americana art.


Fun And Educational!

Throughout the Galleries, visitors will find fascinating biblical and “Did You Know?” exhibits that teach unusual and fun Bible facts.  These interactive resources give scriptural insight into the biblical stories behind each painting and help guests understand the culture and times when the Bible was authored by great men and women of God.


Here's How We Start And How You May Help 

In today’s world it’s continually becoming more difficult to find quality, wholesome entertainment.  We wish to provide uplifting entertainment for all to enjoy and have secured an incredible building at the Gateway Mall in Salt Lake, Utah, in which we would like to open the nation’s first “Bible in Art Galleries”.

This property is a beautifully remodeled facility where the Arnold Friberg art exhibition was held several years ago.  This outstanding facility will become home to the nation’s first "Bible in Art Galleries". 

There will always be something fun to do at the Galleries!  The Celebration Theater will offer continual showings of quality movies.  Live “Christian Praise Bands” will perform mini-concerts every Saturday! The Galleries will partner with a wide selection of favorite restaurants to offer a “Date Night” experience of dining and art.  Those living in assisted living and nursing homes will be treated to monthly field trips to the "Bible in Art Galleries".  Guests may explore God’s underwater creations at the Living Oceans Virtual Aquarium while enjoying a snack at the Galleries Deli.  Incredible brick sculptures and mosaics made from LEGO(r) pieces including Noah’s Ark and the animals, the Tower of Babel, and much more will be on display! 


What will the crowdfunder money be used for?

Purchase of 20 high def video screens- for interactive media shown at the Bible in Art Galleries!

Purchase of Epson 8980 Giclee Printer - for use with reproductions.

Varnished canvas on which the art is printed and framing of images featured in the Galleries - for the best quality reproductions possible!

Appropriate furnishings that will be placed throughout the galleries for guest's comfort.

Security system - to provide security of the art and artifacts contained in the Galleries.

Shuttle van - will be used to provide free trips from the airport, ski resorts, major hotel/motels and other major attrations near Salt Lake city to the Bible in Art Galleries at the Gateway!



Community Outreach and Public Service

BIBLE IN ART GALLERIES is committed to supporting a broad scope of worthy projects in our community.  Our marketing team will be planning and coordinating monthly outings and field trips to the Galleries for those in assisted living, nursing homes, and senior citizen centers.  Because of your support, there will never be a charge for these seniors to visit the Galleries where they can be inspired by the beautiful uplifting art on display in our themed galleries.  In fact, your support allows the Galleries to employ a full time individual whose responsibility is outreach in our community.  In addition, a portion of every admission is donated to the Homeless Shelter and Prison and Jail Ministry Programs.  A list of those organizations the Galleries supports will be published on our website.  Again, these community benefits are all made possible thanks to the generous support of individuals like you.


Incentives:





Additional Silver Incentives

Each SILVER SUPPORTER will get 1 full set of the framed picture ornaments and 2 full sets of the 11"x14" prints.

Up to 200 Silver level supporters will get their name on a plaque that will be displayed at the entrance of the flagship location of the Bible in Art Galleries in Salt Lake City!

Each Silver level supporter will also get a LIMITED-EDITION "Silver supporter Bible in Art Galleries" ornament personalized with their name!  Exclusive to only the Silver level supporters of the Indiegogo campaign!

Silver VIP passes will be included!  These passes are good for unlimited use for you and 5 guests to the Bible in Art Galleries through March 2015.  These passes will also give you access to VIP Events!

As a SILVER SUPPORTER, you'll be able to use your VIP pass for you and 1 guest to the opening celebration that will be catered by The Gateway restaurants.  Look forward to lots of special surprises  on this festive occasion and an exciting one hour program with live music, speakers, and other events!  You’ll also be able to use your SILVER VIP PASS for you and 1 guest to attend future VIP events and openings planned for the Bible in Art Galleries!

Additional Gold Incentives

Each GOLD SUPPORTER will get 3 full set of the framed picture ornaments and 2 full sets of the 11"x14" prints.

Up to 50 Gold level supporters will get their name on a plaque that will be displayed at the entrance of the flagship location of the Bible in Art Galleries in Salt Lake City!

Each Gold level supporter will also get a LIMITED-EDITION "Gold supporter Bible in Art Galleries" ornament personalized with their name!  Exclusive to only the Gold level supporters of the Indiegogo campaign!

Gold VIP passes will be included!  These passes are good for unlimited use for you and 5 guests to the Bible in Art Galleries through the end of 2015.  These passes will also give you access to VIP Events!

As a GOLD SUPPORTER, you'll be able to use your VIP pass for you and 1 guest to the opening celebration that will be catered by The Gateway restaurants.  Look forward to lots of special surprises  on this festive occasion and an exciting one hour program with live music, speakers, and other events!  You’ll also be able to use your GOLD VIP PASS for you and 1 guest to attend future VIP events and openings planned for the Bible in Art Galleries!


Help Play A Part In Changing Lives  

 Whether it's simply sharing this page so others might take advantage of this opportunity, or making a contribution, please consider helping support our campaign so that together we can make the “Bible in Art Galleries” a reality.  Even the smallest amount can make the greatest difference!  To show our appreciation for your support, we have several gifts that include beautiful Christian art for your home.  

May God bless your personal ministry and we’ll be looking forward to seeing you at the Galleries!

Each SILVER SUPPORTER will get 1 full set of the framed picture ornaments and 2 full sets of the 11"x14" prints.
Up to 200 Silver level supporters will get their name on a plaque that will be displayed at the entrance of the flagship location of the Bible in Art Galleries in Salt Lake City!
Each Silver level supporter will also get a LIMITED-EDITION "Silver supporter Bible in Art Galleries" ornament personalized with their name!  Exclusive to only the Silver level supporters of the Indiegogo campaign!
Silver VIP passes will be included!  These passes are good for unlimited use for you and 5 guests to the Bible in Art Galleries through March 2015.  These passes will also give you access to VIP Events!
As a SILVER SUPPORTER, you'll be able to use your VIP pass for you and 1 guest to the opening celebration that will be catered by The Gateway restaurants.  Look forward to lots of special surprises  on this festive occasion and an exciting one hour program with live music, speakers, and other events!  You’ll also be able to use your SILVER VIP PASS for you and 1 guest to attend future VIP events and openings planned for the Bible in Art Galleries!

Additional Gold Incentives
Each GOLD SUPPORTER will get 3 full set of the framed picture ornaments and 2 full sets of the 11"x14" prints.
Up to 50 Gold level supporters will get their name on a plaque that 
will be displayed at the entrance of the flagship location of the Bible in 
Art Galleries in Salt Lake City!
Each Gold level supporter will also get a LIMITED-EDITION "Gold 
supporter Bible in Art Galleries" ornament personalized with their name!  Exclusive to only the Gold level supporters of the Indiegogo 
campaign!

Gold VIP passes will be included!  These passes are good for 
unlimited use for you and 5 guests to the Bible in Art Galleries through the end of 2015.  These
 passes will also give you access to VIP Events!
As a GOLD SUPPORTER, you'll be able to use your VIP pass for you and 1
 guest to the opening celebration that will be catered by The Gateway 
restaurants.  Look forward to lots of special surprises  on this festive
 occasion and an exciting one hour program with live music, speakers, 
and other events!  You’ll also be able to use your GOLD VIP PASS for 
you and 1 guest to attend future VIP events and openings planned for the
 Bible in Art Galleries!

Help Play A Part In Changing Lives  
 Whether it's simply sharing this page so others might take advantage of this opportunity, or making a contribution, please consider helping support our campaign so that together we can make the “Bible in Art Galleries” a reality.  Even the smallest amount can make the greatest difference!  To show our appreciation for your support, we have several gifts that include beautiful Christian art for your home.  
May God bless your personal ministry and we’ll be looking forward to seeing you at the Galleries!

story:
Our Story

Sky Pirates of Valendor is a fantasy comic book series created by Everett Soares and published by Free Lunch Comics. So far, we have published a five issue mini series, a collected trade paperback that was distributed through Diamond Distributors and an anthology of short stories. We've even launched a webcomic while preparing for our 2nd volume of books.

 

Those who have seen us at conventions know that 2010 was the year for merchandising. We now have t-shirts, coffee mugs and even engraved flasks!

 

Now we are embarking on one of our largest projects ever - a 2011 calendar featuring artwork from 13 different artists. These artists are scattered around the world and the calendar will see the widest distribution for Sky Pirates yet! 

 

Here is a slideshow of the art to be included in the calendar:

 

http://s809.photobucket.com/albums/zz15/sjscomi...

story:
Introduction

The collection, Catalina’s Bells, is a community development project that consists of the publication of 150 copies for each of five books demonstrating some of the panorama of new Latin American poetry. Each of the five of these bilingual books (Spanish and English) will have a distinct artistic concept, and each book will have its own cover, as they will be made of recycled materials in art workshops by youth and adults.

Each book will present the poetry of three authors of a particular country. For this first collection we have chosen Argentina, Chile, Ecuador, Peru and Mexico. The works will be translated by academics and writers from the United States.

The books will be distributed in public libraries, bookstores and universities, and presentations will be held at poetry festivals and cultural centers in various countries of the American continent.

Catalina´s Bells is a project of Cardboard House Press

Background

The workshop for craft and art books was born in Bloomington in June 2012 when Giancarlo Huapaya and Cristian Medina organized the first space for processing cardboard into books in Bloomington, Indiana. Giancarlo came with experience conducting workshops to implement cartoneras libraries in communities of Peru, and a few years ago, he participated as an author at the Cartonero Fair Book Mercosur in Asunción, Paraguay, which brought together all cardboard book publishers (“cartoneras”) of Latin America. Meanwhile Cristian is a connoisseur of contemporary poetry and of the phenomenon of independent publishing. They, along with the poet and critic, Paul Guillen, researcher of new Latin American and American poetry, decided to form The Cardboard House Press, a publisher that not only thinks of the end result of the product book, but also of the production process as a vital aspect of community development. Our project, then, consists of developing unique products with artistic values through participatory and educational processes.

Goal

To edit, produce and publish five books that demonstrate a panoramic view of contemporary Latin American poetry through processes that generate educational and social development .

Why art books?

In times where everything has been digitized and people are commonly connected to an electronic device, the art book project proposes to create the bonds of ownership, appreciation, and revaluing of the physical book, of the book that can be felt with the senses, that through its production educates and offers social development to its community and region, made by the hands of authors, translators, producers and artists for the hands, spirits, and minds of hundreds of people.

story:
Description

Future Face is a series of illustrations depicting portraits of beautiful female androids. In 2010, it started as just a couple of illustrations I wanted to do at the time and evolved into an ongoing series. Since then I’ve created 24 entries in this series. The book will include additional images showing the process from start to finish. This book will make for a perfect addition to your home, office, or studio.

This hard cover book is 8.3” x 11.7” (A4)

Perk 1 will get you 1 copy of the book for $35.

Perk 2 will get you 2 copies for $65.

There is an additional fee for shipping.

FYI - The book in the video and gallery is a digital mock-up and not a physical copy of the book.

Preview

To view the rest of the illustrations, visit billynunez.com/Future-Face

story:
The Story of SPARKcon 

SPARKcon is an interdisciplinary creativity, art & design festival produced by the non-profit creativity incubator, Visual Art Exchange, in Raleigh NC. SPARKcon 2014 will be the 9th annual event and will be held Sept. 11-14 in downtown Raleigh.

September 2014 will be our nineth annual SPARKcon. Each year we activate an open-invitation group of volunteers. SPARKcon is open to any passionate individual or group who wants to get involved. We’re grass roots—our money comes from our pockets and the pockets of others excited to support local creativity. The ideas and showcases come from inspired people who have the ingenuity to say “What if…?” and the motivation to then help make it happen.

SPARKcon’s “creative potluck” of SPARKs or creative themes such as art, music, film, fashion, geek, circus, etc.  is put together by passionate individuals who volunteer their expertise and are deeply embedded in a specific local scene. Using a combination of networking and open calls for participants, organizers create diverse and representative events to show off local talent and connect disparate creative scenes. 

This year, we have over 80 organizers, hundreds of local talents will be showcased, hundreds of volunteers will helping behind the scenes and thousands of attendees. All of these people equal SPARKcon.

Gallery of Awesomeness

See the gallery of images and a video explaining the opensource model from past SPARKcons!

Why We Gogo

As SPARKcon grows, so does the budget (ain't it funny how that happens?). This year, we anticipate budgetary needs to be upwards of $200k: $100k in in-kind donations (meaning totally awesome people and organizations donating their time or their stuffs) AND $100k+ of cold hard cash to make it happen. All this money goes to the production and logistics of the events. Most of the organizers, the visionaries and talent are passionate volunteers.

Indiegogo is such a beautiful representation of a community-based funding process, that we have to embrace it! Our goal is to realize at least 10% of our cash budget needs through this Indiegogo campaign.

Each year, we ask for our community to engage with SPARKcon and help make it happen through awesome contributions of time, talent, know-how and, yes, money. 

Your support helps make it happen! The budget goes towards:

• Creating a super festival featuring 2,000+ local creatives in 200+ events!

• Allowing SPARKcon to be free and open to everyone!

• Paying sound techs, stage and lighting techs and other production talents

• Renting equipment like video screens and projectors and buying supplies

SPARKcon keeps the Triangle creative. By helping artists plan their own showcases and grow their professional skill sets and networks, this festival helps build careers and create leaders. And educate everyone about the next big thing! 

What happens if we don't meet our goal?
We will always have SPARKcon! Our artists always find a way! That said, your support is needed to help us purchase supplies, pay artists, build new audiences and inspire more people.

This year is so SPARKly!

SPARKcon grows every time a new person gets involved with a SPARK category, creating their own event, or joining in to help an existing one. It’s an open-source, “for the people, by the people” approach with an intentionally dynamic focus and will feature 2,000 artists in 200+ events. Each segment of the creative community plans their own "SPARKs" to showcase their talent.

artSPARK

Many many many artists of all ages are involved with artSPARK. There are a host of installations, exhibitions, workshops AND chalk art covering three entire city block lengths of Fayetteville St! See how the local artist community expresses creativity!

bazaarSPARK

Enjoy a city block worth of local artisans, brands, food, fashion and friends as an outdoor shopping experience. What if the mall was cool and celebrated local goods? It would be bazaarSPARK.

circusSPARK

Be ready for serious fun with a big talented local community of circus performers! Acrobatics, hoops, fire dancers, a bit of magic and, of course, the banana dance!

comedySPARK

Quick!  Tell us a joke!  Not a problem for these folks.  From buses to bathrooms, it's laugh out loud fun!

danceSPARK

The SPARKcon main stage will be chock full of expressions of dance. Be ready to see the great variety and talent of our local dance community.

designSPARK

Showcasing the local talents of our design community - architecture, interior design, graphic design, product design, motion design, etc - they're all here and they're all awesome.

fashionSPARK

The fashionSPARK fashion show is the largest and most popular annual fashion event in the Triangle! This year, also enjoy jewelrySPARK, a trunk show featuring work by the area’s most talented jewelry designers.

filmSPARK

Experience a showcase of local independent films and shorts in drama, comedy, thriller, documentary, animation, experimental & effects, and music video—all on a giant downtown screen!

geekSPARK

Be wowed by the latest new and interactive media and technologies. Whether it's a large video game studio, or a solitary multi-disciplinary genius, geekSPARK showcases an awesome blend of art, technology and creativity.

ideaSPARK

Get into it with fast-action presentations of 20 slides / 20 seconds per slide. Each year ideaSPARK influences the area, including the design of Raleigh City Plaza and the inclusion of local designers in city proposal requests.

musicSPARK

Find lots of different types of music - the awesomeness you might not have even known was here - and celebrate it in clubs and on stages throughout downtown Raleigh.

poetrySPARK

From Best of the Open Mic and a Featured Reading, to erotic verse after dark and Poetry on Demand – we present verse in ways that will be remembered.

theatreSPARK

It's all an act - seriously. Enjoy a variety of styles and talents in theatre productions and excerpts designed to celebrate and promote our local community of actors.

There are Perks!

Cool T-shirts, primo event seats, behind-the-scenes access, love, gratitude, high fives—and most importantly, the great feeling that comes with supporting your local community and helping creative people do amazing things.


Other Ways You Can Help

Volunteer! It takes a lot of people to make this work!

Share this campaign. There are easy Indiegogo share tools!

More about SPARKcon:

SPARKcon is a showcase of creativity, talent and ideas of “The Creative Hub of the South,” the Triangle of NC.

SPARKcon was founded in 2006 by Beth and Aly Khalifa and Designbox to showcase, celebrate and influence the creative momentum of the Triangle region of North Carolina. SPARKcon uses an open-source organizational approach to empower diverse creative thinkers to be inspiring community leaders.

SPARKcon is a program of Visual Art Exchange, a Raleigh non-profit whose mission is to support emerging artists and connect the community to the arts.

SPARKcon’s name comes from being a conference to “spark” the local art community and brand the Triangle as the creative hub of the South. SPARKcon uses an innovative event structure to connect and showcase the growing creative community in the Triangle. Each category is called a “SPARK” (musicSPARK, fashionSPARK, etc.) and is organized by volunteers who create programming that best represents their art form, whether a performance, an exhibition, showcase or interactive digital game.

Visit SPARKcon.com to get detailed information. The schedule of events will be online as well when we get closer to the dates. And please join us in downtown Raleigh for SPARKcon on September 11-14 2014!

story:
Short Summary

Rhiannon McCullough is a feelance artist from Rhode Island. The artist behind the “Chibi Mentality Project” and the webcomic Broken Windmills, with an MFA in Asian Studies at the University of Hawai’i Manoa.

This fund is to pay for the price of commission on the illustration of the in game tapestry commissioned by Iweko Miaka to commemorate her encounter with the Oni. My commission price for a piece like this is fairly high because of the level of detail. While simple avatars take little time and effort a large commission involves much more attention. It is unlikely a single player would be able to pay the commission cost. This allows the project to be funded without any one individual shouldering the cost of commission and allows me to offer prints at a reduced price to those players who might otherwise be unable to afford them.

What We Need & What You Get


I will be making prints available to purchase once the commission is finished. But the first five supporters to pledge $50 or more will receive a signed print as part of their contribution.

Other Ways You Can Help


If you can not contribute please spread the word within the community, even those who were not active in Court are welcome to participate.

story:
THE BASICS

Each year, Ann Arbor Poetry & Slam works to put on affordable programming and send a team to Nationals to compete at the National Poetry Slam in August. We operate strictly on a donation-basis so as to ensure that our space is always vibrant, safe, and inclusive.

Usually, we enter a new season with depleted funds due to the costs associated with registration, travel, etc. This year, we're looking to do our fundraising early in order to not only support this year's team, but next year's team, and to also get a pool of funds that will allow us to support some of the top artists in the country to come visit and share their work with our community.

We have a reputation as one of the longest-running, open slams in the nation, and we'd love your support in this very brief micro-drive [only one week to donate]! 

What We Need & What You Get

Whatever you'd like to donate. We know that in this digital age, it becomes difficult for people to contribute cash funds at the door of our events, so we figured we'd open up a way for you to donate directly to us online.

  • Every dollar you share with us goes right back into feeding the community and the slam. Our only costs come about in national competition expenses, publicity [fliers, etc], and bringing featured poets in-- never ourselves [as we do this on a volunteer basis across the board. Additionally, we have some equipment that is starting to see some wear, so being able to maintain that will be another use of the funds.

  • Every cent helps us run an event that you can enjoy, and allows us to curate a set of the biggest names in poetry from across the country. The better our funding pool early on, the better we'll be able to serve you.

  • When it comes to perks, they are plentiful. You can get anything from a t-shirt to our newly designed poetry posters to a coveted position on our newly formed Advisory Council.

The Impact

Our goal is a modest one: to raise any amount of funds we can to feed back into the community and offer you all a show you can be proud of. By funding us, you're ensuring a series of events and a cultivation of community that continues to be one of the best and longest-running in the country.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share, share, share! No donation is too small, and no word of support goes unheard. We value each and every person, and their desire to contribute to the Ann Arbor Poetry family-- in whatever way they choose.

story:
We have made our goal 3 days before the end of the campaign! Thank you!

AWA will put any further funds towards collateral projects related to the restoration of Nelli’s masterpiece. The amount we set out to raise here on Indiegogo is just enough to cover the restorer’s fees, but for every AWA project, as you know, we always produce a book to share the results of the research and restoration, and when possible also a documentary film. These are additional costs that we consider well spent because this material helps spread the word about women artists and their achievements.

 

 

Plautilla Nelli was an important artist in sixteenth-century Florence, Italy. Her paintings were found in churches and in the homes of many nobles. Yet until about 10 years ago, few had ever heard of her, and she’s still not a household name. We at the Advancing Women Artists Foundation (AWA) want to change that, and the fact that you’re reading this is a first step!

Nelli was the starting point for our first decade of research and restoration; now we hope Nelli will inspire you to get involved in the restoration of her greatest masterpiece - a 22-foot canvas depicting a Last Supper, a subject that no woman before or after her has addressed.

This is #TheFirstLast: the First "Last Supper" by a woman, by the First documented female artist in Florence. It is the largest work of art by an early modern woman. It has been hidden from the public eye for 450 years and this restoration will put it, and Nelli, in the spotlight.

Women from all around the world have gotten behind this project, putting their energy and enthusiasm into it. Listen to their own words about why THEY support Nelli!

 

 

 
 

NOTE: Advancing Women Artists Foundation is an American not-for-profit (501c3). Your contributions here on Indiegogo are tax deductible in the USA.

 

 

Our founder, philanthropist Jane Fortune, “met” Nelli on a visit to Florence’s San Marco Museum in 2005. Nelli’s painting, Lamentation with Saints, moved her; Nelli as an artist intrigued her. This is the first documented woman painter of Florence, who was celebrated in Vasari’s Lives and had created a vast body of works, but Jane, an art lover, had never heard of her. She asked herself: “how many other works by women are hanging on museum walls or hiding in storage, forgotten by history?”.

[Jane Fortune looking at a Lunette painted by Plautilla Nelli at the San Salvi museum in Florence]

Sparked by Nelli’s formidable talent, Jane embarked on a quest to uncover more works by women artists in Florence. She and her team made an inventory of over 2,000 paintings, drawings and sculptures by women from the 16th to the 20th centuries. Many of these are in storage and are in need of restoration. Jane created the Advancing Women Artists Foundation (AWA) to help them get out of storage and into the public eye. In the past decade, the foundation Fortune established has restored over forty of these works, and shed further light on them through books and documentaries for the general public, such as the Emmy-award-winning PBS documentary “Invisible Women.”

Polissena Nelli was born in Florence 1523; at the age of 14, in 1538, she entered the Dominican convent of Santa Caterina da Siena and took her vows as a nun, adopting the name Plautilla. The convent, which no longer exists, was located in Piazza San Marco and was governed by that monastery’s friars.

Contrary to how we might imagine convents today, in the Renaissance they were home to many wealthy, educated women, and these women enjoyed freedoms that their married counterparts did not. One of these was to pursue an artistic career, considered inappropriate and downright impossible for women. Noble women might paint small canvases as dilettantes, but could not sell their work. By being a nun artist, Nelli broke the mold.

[Plautilla Nelli, Lamentation with Saints, Museo di San Marco, restored by AWA]

Nelli’s convent was initially known for the production of terracotta objects. In this context where craftsmanship was key, she taught herself art using drawings and prints and began to sell her paintings. Recent studies of the convent account books reveal that, as demand for Nelli’s art grew, she instructed her sisters and set up an actual painting workshop, parallel in organization to the ones by her lay counterparts, whose income made the convent self-sufficient. The full extent of this workshop and its impact has yet to be studied.

Giorgio Vasari, who is considered the first art historian, mentions Nelli in his important book about the Lives of the Artists (1568 edition), saying "she would have done wonderful things if she had had the chance to study as men do." We believe she has done great things, and we're working to discover and restore them, one by one.

(This pre-restoration image shows the grimy yellow varnish that was used to cover the painting's fine details, and the in-painting added centuries ago where original paint is lost.)

The Last Supper is Nelli’s largest and most ambitious work, painted for the nuns’ dining room in her own convent. Picture this. The painting is oil on canvas, and it’s huge: 22 feet wide and 5.6 feet tall, composed of numerous pieces of canvas stitched together and mounted on a wooden support. It depicts the biblical scene of Christ and the Apostles at table, when Jesus reveals that one of them (Judas, seated at the front of the table) will betray him.

There’s a lot that is remarkable about this painting. First and foremost, think about how massive the task must have been for a woman at this time, an artist who likely received no professional training at all! Even just facing the blank canvas must have been daunting. Firstly, she had  to lay out the composition, which she would have done by drawing large cartoons and transferring their outlines to the canvas. Then she had to have the willpower and downright patience to cover that 14 square meters or so in paint, sometimes using the smallest of brushes.

Another very interesting fact that emerges is that one does not go about stretching a canvas like this on one’s own. Nelli must have engaged outside workmen to build the frame and prepare the canvas, which adds to our understanding of a rather open, permeable convent in which these women lived.

And last but not least, Nelli had the ability and pure guts to paint a subject matter that her contemporaries considered the ultimate test of artistic ability. She looked to Leonardo da Vinci’s famous fresco in Milan (which she knew probably through prints), as well as to important examples nearby. She was the first woman artist to deal with this topic, and as far as we know, she was also the last.

Nelli’s Last Supper is in dire need of restoration; it has lost a lot of paint that hinders its legibility. The convent of Santa Caterina da Siena was closed under Napoleon, and it seems that the painting was rolled up and put in storage for some time before it found a new home in the monastery of Santa Maria Novella, where until recently it was hung in the monks’ private dining room.

[In this detail of the left side of the painting, the restorer has removed the varnish and in-painting to reveal the artist's own color choices and brushstrokes. It looks "ruined" but it is on its way to recovery.]

The restoration job involves the following steps. Consolidation of the work on its support: being made of multiple pieces of canvas stitched together, it has started to sag. Removal of a thick yellow varnish that was applied in the past, to reveal the original paint. Conservation of the original paint where it is flaking off. Conservative infilling where paint has been lost. Florentine Conservator Rossella Lari has estimated that it will take her 1750 hours over 2 years to do this work.

In this particular case, there is still a lot to learn about the Last Supper. Rossella Lari is perhaps the person who is closest to Nelli right now, quite literally as she works millimeter by millimeter on the painting. Through observation, aided by high-tech machinery, she will write a restoration report about Nelli’s painting that will be a first step to guide future scholarship. What she finds is likely to provide clues or answers to many things, from the work’s physical history to the specific iconography of the painting as she removes the grime to reveal previously unseen details.

It is very rare for conservationists to have the opportunity to restore works by historic female artists, so when the opportunity arises, we believe that modern-day women should be given that chance. Restoration sponsored by AWA plays a dual role. On the one hand, it allows us to rescue paintings and sculptures from decay. On the other, it is a tool for reclaiming these artists’ stories, and in this case for reclaiming the usually man-centric historical period of the Renaissance.

By restoring a work, we begin to study it, understand it, talk about it, and exhibit it. These are all essential parts of giving these artists’ their rightful place in history. You cannot love something you do not know. You cannot protect something you do not love. So, ultimately restoration gives people the opportunity to know and love an artist like Nelli.

The Last Supper Team is supported by several ‘front-line’ volunteers based in Florence: Leslie Jmaeff, Lucia Bucciarelli, Poiret Masse, Margherita Agostini, Torie Gray and Ann Piper, who are art historians, students or art lovers committed to the project via cultural liaison work, press support, international communication and social media.  In addition this project is supported by the graphics and strategy team at Flod.

Heading into our next decade, we want to continue Jane’s legacy by getting more people involved in AWA’s projects. Crowdfunding is the perfect way to do that: this project is not just about raising money, but of the value of your voice as you learn about and share Nelli’s experience and that of other women artists.

That said, this specific project needs to be completed, and we need to raise money to do this. The Last Supper is the most ambitious restoration we’ve done so far. The restoration alone costs €85,000, which includes the specialist’s time, materials and scientific analysis. AWA has raised the amount to cover the first phase, while we are hoping to raise the $65,000 required for the second phase of restoration here on Indiegogo. The chart below shows how these costs are broken down.

In addition to the cost of the restoration, it’s very important to us that we diffuse information about the works we restore. If we raise additional funds on this platform, those will go towards: professional photography and video documentation of the restoration process and finished product; research, writing, layout and publication of a book dedicated to Nelli’s Last Supper.

Is my donation tax deductible?

AWA is a certified 501(c)(3) non-profit foundation in the USA. Each donation you make today is entirely tax deductible. You will receive a tax receipt from AWA after the campaign ends and payments are processed.

Can my company get involved / donate?

Absolutely! We would be happy to work out a custom, tax-deductible corporate reward for you based on your interests. Please get in touch with jane.adams@advancingwomenartists.org.

Can I give for more than one reward?

Yes, you can (thanks!). This has to be done in two separate transactions. Make your first choice by mousing over the reward you want (the button then turns pink), and complete the transaction; then, return to the project page and do the second one. [See the IGG Help article on this]

How can I donate but NOT choose a reward?

Thank you! Simply click the pink "BACK IT" button at the TOP of this campaign. Please note, if you do this, you don't get the choice of a reward. If you want a reward, follow the process in the step by step guide we made in English (oppure in Italiano).

I'm having trouble contributing, can you help me?

We'd love to help you. First you might want to see if your problem is covered here. Second, see if you can follow the step by step guide we made in English (oppure in Italiano). If you need guidance please write to us (info @ advancingwomenartists.org) and we'll try to help!

Can I pay with Paypal?

Sorry, unfortunately not. Indiegogo has recently changed payment providers and no longer accepts payments through Paypal. All major credit cards are accepted.

Can I pay by check or bank transfer?

We are happy to accept donations in any form. Please contact us if you prefer not to use a credit card and we will find a solution.

 

PARTNERS AND SPONSORS

Media partner: The Florentine

Prize sponsors:

Rocco Forte Hotel Savoy

Medici Dynasty Show

Nerdi Orafo Firenze

Aqua Flor Firenze
