story:
What is TBD?!

 

Austin Young is proud to announce the launch of his latest project, TBD: A Musical Play and Video by EVERYONE Who Comes.

 

In contrast to the exclusivity of Hollywood or Broadway productions, this is a musical emphasizing radical authenticity and spontaneous creativity, and will be the most unusual and revolutionary musical you have ever experienced.  For this production, Austin Young invites the public to join in for a series 7 workshops where twe will co-create, sharing our stories and experiences around the topic of  ‘coming of age’  and produce a beautiful, unconventional, experimental and collaborative musical about everyone who comes. Our shared experiences during this time will become a co-authored  feature length video, and an illustrated screenplay. all staring you!

 

How it is Happening

 

There will be a series of 7 workshops over 3 weeks where the public is invited to become co-creators by attending one or more workshops during the run of the production.  Each workshop will become a musical number in the final feature  video documentation.

To participate think of a story about growing up. It can be yours or someone else’s that had an influence on. Sign up for the workshop of your choice. What would you prefer to do: dance, sing, play music, and/or make costumes? You’ll receive a list of instructions.  Have fun. Be yourself.  It’s that easy!

 

WORKSHOPS: from July 20th to August 9rd. 
workshops are free to the public. *there is an expense fee for the scent workshop.

WORKSHOP LEADERS and CONTRIBUTORS:

Abby Travis

Nina Mcneelly -

Squeaky Blonde

Fade-Dra

FOL CHEN

Austin Young-

Lenora Claire

Machine Project

BEACH  (aka Bitch)

Juliana Snapper

Margaret Cho

The Killsisters

Phranc

Miller Puckette

The Heathers

TRANIMAL Workshop

Cake and Eat It

Institute for Art and Olfaction

Smell Bent

Accident

WIFE

Sharon McGunigle Aka Venus DeMille

Makeup provided by MAC cosmetics

Workshops space provided by Maker City LA and Machine Project Gallery

Video by Kurt Keppeler and Austin Young

Chloë Flores

 

What We Need

Your help is greatly needed! The more you can give, the more fabulous this will be. To make this project successful, I need to rent lighting and camera equpment. I will need to pay workshop leaders and provide needed supplies like fabric, clothes, mask making materials, paint, digital storage, a stenographer, and props as well as drinks and refreshments. I will need to hire a graphic designer to help put the screenplay in manuscript form, pay a video editor to edit the footage collected, and pay assistants to organize the photos and ephemera collected during the show.

It's a lot but I know we can do it!

 

 TBD Workshops:  email austin@austinyoung.com with TBD in the subject line and list your top choices for the workshops you'd like to attend. When your workshop is confirmed, you will receive instructions on how to participate.

 

Saturday, July 20th (12-7pm) :  Things Unspoken with Juliana Snapper / Miller Puckette/ TRANIMAL Workshop (Squeaky Blonde, Fade-Dra and Austin Young)

Vocal performance, art. : In this workshop we will use costumes, sound, body and voice to express what words can't convey . Your pain. Your desires. Your shame. Your anger. Your obsessions. Your heartbreak.Your silence and noise. Your fear. Your alienation. Your desolation.Your ID.Then give it up to your inner TRANIMAL . (limited to 6 participants)

Monday, July 29th (6–9pm):  Smells Like Teen Spirit with The Institute for Art and Olfaction

Scent workshop, story telling: Write down a secret from your youth. Put it in a hat. Someone else will read it. Create a perfume for your inner teenager. (limited to 8 participants. there is a fee for materials sign up here: http://teenspirit.eventbrite.com/ )

 

Thursday, August 1st (12-8pm):  The Halls of My Highschool with Beach (aka Bitch)  / styling by Cake and Eat It.

Singing, dancing, acting: The halls of high school are like a war zone. Bring a hall pass and a note from your mother, a high school hallway (or hallway adjacent) story to share, and, if it involves props, to bring those too! (limited to 15 participants)

 

Saturday, August 3rd (3-8pm) :  Coming of Age with Nina Mcneely

Dancing: When hormones go wild, love is a battlefield ... bring a friend. (limited to 30 participants)

 

Sunday, August 4th  (2-8pm): Campfire Crush with Phranc

Story telling, singing:  It's summer camp. It can get cold. bring proper camp attire and a flashlight.  Who are you crushed out on? I've been thinking of all the camp songs I know. Especially that tune mentioning the "calf with the mournful eye". Remember that one?? Oy! (limited to 15 participants)

 

August 7th and 8th (5-10 pm):  Who Am I (part 1 and 2) with Fol Chen / Machine Project / Austin Young / costumes provided by Sharon McGunigle

Story telling, singing:  bring a pop song and a story that stands out when you were coming of age. Who am i? Don't dream it. Be it!  I'm punk rock. I'm new wave.  I'm straight. I'm gay. I'm cool.  (limited to 10 participants- you must attend both workshops)

 

August 9th: Slumber Party (2-12pm) - KILLSISTERS / WIFE / ACCIDENT/ hosted by Lenora Claire    
(Final workshop, and launch of Austin Young’s 'Accident', by Brent Leonesio, an art edition of 100 scents created with The Institute for Art and Olfaction).
Singing, dancing, acting, story telling:  Pillow fights. Ouiji boards. Toilet Paper. Light as a feather, stiff as a board. Truth or dare. Spin the bottle. Roulette chat. Facebook stalking. Three-way calls.  We will act out our slumber party stories. bring necessary props. (no limit to participants)

 

A Little Bit of Background  

 

Austin young is a pop-culture architect, photographer and trans media artist. Young has been documenting pop, celebrity, sub, and trans culture since 1985 through portraiture. Young's video works play with pop-culture and camp, celebrity, gender and identity. His photographs have been featured in major publications such as Interview Magazine, OK, and Flaunt and have been in solo exhibitions and projects at LACMA (Los Angeles, CA), Machine Project (Los Angeles, CA), Hammer Museum (Los Angeles, CA), Berkeley Art Museum (Berkley, California); and as well as groups shows at Los Angeles Contemporary Exhibitions (Los Angeles, CA) and Stephen Cohen Gallery (Los Angeles, CA).  They have been shown at festivals including Frameline, MIX.  In addition to photography and filmmaking, Young is co-founder of Fallen Fruit, an art collective who use fruit as a common denominator to change the way you think about the world. Fallen Fruit has had major exhibitions at Los Angeles County Museum of Art; Hammer Museum; Salt Lake Art Center (Salt Lake City, Utah), Machine Project, Matadero (Madrid, Spain); LACE (Los Angeles) and ARS Electronic (Austria). Fallen Fruit is a Creative Capital grantee for 2013 and just completed LA counties first public fruit park in Del Aire with a grant from the LA County Art's commission.

 

austinyoung.com

 -------------------------------------------
 
Fol Chen

Fol Chen has created a signature sound from field recordings and an electronic junk drawer, building compound beats and sending warped vocal transmissions. Led by producers Samuel Bing and Julian Wass, Fol Chen's first two records, PART I: John Shade, Your Fortune's Made (Asthmatic Kitty, 2009) and PART II: The New December (Asthmatic Kitty, 2010), cemented the band's place as peddlers of dark pop in the alleys of independent music. Their live entity has a wide artistic reach with a propensity for interactive projects like the Tetrafol, a motion-based sound toy developed with musical interface pioneers Monome. Band events have been presented at sites such as the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, the Annenberg Space for Photography, and the Walker Art Center.

THE FALSE ALARMS out now on Asthmatic Kitty Records: www.bit.ly/fol_chen_4sale

 -------------------------------------------

Tranimal Workshop:

Tranimal workshop, a collaboration between Austin Young, Squeaky Blonde, Fade-dra, and the public, is a participatory event where gallery or museum attendees are invited to go through a conveyer belt of artists and become the art. Tranimal workshop changes the way you consider gender, beauty and identity. “one of 2010’s top ten fashion trends in la” - Lina Lecaro, LA Weekly. Tranimal workshop has shown at Machine Project (Los Angeles) in 2009-2013 , Hammer Museum in 2010 (Los Angeles) , Machine Project at the Berkeley Art Museum in 2011, 7 Hollywood Magazine spread, 2013.

http://www.austinyoung.com/projects/tranimal/

---------------------------------------------

Squeaky Blonde

Re: Squeaky blonde is an la based performance artist, musician, actor  and designer. Who's work has been showcased at LACMA , the hammer museum, Berkeley Art Museum , and Machine Project and in publications such as Art Forum, 7 Hollywood, Paper Magazine,   Oblivion, LA Weekly, Propaganda ,Frontiers and BUTT magazine. he's has been a nightlife personality for nearly 2 decades and continues to charm and terrorize audiences worldwide.  His unique style blends elements of macabre high art with occult overtones , facets of surrealistic  and maniacal hedonism topped with a dash  of dadaesque lunacy that compliments his unique vocal range and operatic schrei.  Visit www.squeakyblonde.com for upcoming dates and future projects.

-------------------------------------------

Machine Project:

Machine Project is a storefront space in the echo park neighborhood of Los Angeles that hosts events about all kinds of things we find interesting – scientific talks, poetry readings, musical performances, competitions, group naps, cheese tastings and so forth. We usually do about two events a week, open to the general public and free of charge.

Machine Project is an informal educational institution that teaches all kinds of things they  find interesting – electronics, sewing, pickling, computer programming, car theft and so forth. Machine Project is a loose group of artist/performer collaborators, who do projects together when invited by other people and institutions, usually museums.

http://machineproject.com


-------------------------------------------

Fade-Dra:

Fade-Dra is an artist with Tranimal workshop and the notorious and club performer, his iconic fashion is celebrated worldwide.

https://www.facebook.com/fadedra

-------------------------------------------

BEACH:

Bitch is a singer who plays electric violin, bass, ukulele and keytar.   She just recently ‘came out’ with her birth name, Karen Mould, to mark her recent shift in sound, and launched her new project, BEACH. BEACH is indie-electro rock fronted by her electric violin.  She is joined on stage by an Alligator who operates the “machine.”   Together, they make hopeful, sometimes funny and poetically serious dance-y rock. Karen started studying classical violin at 4, and later expanded her musical horizons by studying fiddling with Andrew Bird.  Her band, Bitch and Animal, toured with Ani Difranco in the U.S. and Europe and released two albums on Difranco’s label, Righteous Babe Records.

She starred as Bitch in the John Cameron Mitchell film Shortbus, which premiered at theCannes Film Festival.  The artist went on to release her first solo album Make This Break This onKill Rock Stars.   In 2008, she started her own label, Short Story Records and released an ep B+TEC! with her Brooklyn-based rock trio Bitch +The Exciting Conclusion.  

That same year, Bitch produced and released an entire album of one of her musical idols, Ferron, called Boulder.  Boulder features performances by  Ani Difranco, Amy Ray and Emily Saliers of the Indigo Girls, JD Samson, (Le Tigre, MEN) and Samantha Parton (The Be Good Tanyas).  In 2010, she released Blasted! on Short Story Records, funded entirely by her fans via Kickstarter. Bitch has also recently completed Thunder & Lighten-ing, a documentary and new album she and Billie Jo Cavallaro have produced of Ferron, which will also be released on Short Story in 2013.

http://bitchmusic.com/
-------------------------------------------
 
Julianna Snapper

Juliana Snapper is an opera singer, voice researcher and artist. She received her B.M. in vocal performance from the Oberlin Conservatory where she studied under Richard Miller, and her M.A. in critical musicology at University of California, San Diego.

Snapper creates performances and installations that push the physical and expressive capacities of the singing body. She combines radical vocal techniques, composition, improvisation, and intermedia dynamics alone and in collaboration. Snapper collaborated with performance artist Ron Athey on the piece Judas Cradle which toured throughout the U.K. and premiered in the U.S. at Walt Disney Concert Hall's REDCAT Theatre. Her Five Fathoms Opera Project premiered in 2008 at P.S.1 Contemporary Art Center/MoMA NY. In May 2009, she collaborated with composer Andrew Infanti and costume designer Susan Matheson on the premiere of the world's first underwater opera You who will emerge from the flood at the Victoria Baths in Manchester, U.K. It is part of an episodic and site-specific work that has since been staged in the U.S., France, Portugal, Poland, and Switzerland.

Her projects have been supported by grants and fellowships from The Metropolitan Opera Foundation, Arts Council of Great Britain, The Center for Research in Computing in the Arts, and The Durfee Foundation.

http://julianasnapper.org/

----------------------------------

Nina McNeely:

Nina McNeely is a choreographer, dancer, director, animator, and video editor, based on Los Angeles. She started her career as a commercial dancer, dancing for pop icons like Britney Spears and the B52's.  She soon found herself experimenting with performance and choreography in the underground club scene and local contemporary dance companies such as Hysterica Dance Company and Collage Dance theater. After years of working in the industry and traveling the globe as a performer, she was inspired to explore the other side of the camera. Since then she has directed music videos for artists such as Dorian Wood and Kids Without Instruments, edits fashion films for Elle Magazine and has recently choreographed for Major Lazer, Sam Sparro, Yeasayer, and Big Black Delta.  She is a founding member of WIFE where she choreographs, conceptualizes and creates animations for projection mapping. WIFE has been commissioned by Ford Fusion curated by LEGS and Milk Studios, TEDex Socal, MOCA TV and is featured on electronic artist Amon Tobin's DVD box set. Nina McNeely is also a dance teacher. She has taught her unique style around the country, at Edge performing arts in Los Angeles, and is currently teaching a non-dancer beginning contemporary class at The Sweat Spot in Silverlake.

 Website:  cargocollective.com/ninamcneely

-------------------------------------------

Sharon McGunigle Aka Venus DeMille

With an MFA in Costume Design, Sharon has been designing and constructing costumes for Film, Theatre, Opera, Burlesque, Cosplay, Clowns and Aerial Artists for the last 25 years. She has been the Head Tailor at the LA Opera for over 10 years.

She is the resident costume designer for the critically acclaimed Troubadour Theatre Company (Troubie.com) having received an LA Stage Alliance Ovation Award for costume Design for “Alice in One-Hit Wonderland; Through the Looking Glass.” Recent productions include Rudolph the Red-Nosed ReinDoors and A Midsummer Saturday Night’s Fever Dream. She has also designed for Actor’s Co-Op and the Colony Theatre.

As Tailor/Cutter for the LA Opera for 13 seasons, she has worked on many world-class productions, including Achim Freyer’s Ring Cycle, Robert Wilson’s Madame Butterfly, The Black Rider, Il Postino, and the upcoming Komische Oper production of The Magic Flute. (LAOpera.com)

Under the name Venus DeMille she has been an integral part of the nationwide neo-burlesque scene since joining the Velvet Hammer Burlesque in 2002. She was crowned “Legend in the Making” at the very last Miss Exotic World Pageant held on the infamous goat farm in 2005. She has created costumes for many of LA’s Burlesque Starlets including Jewel of Denial, Princess Farhana, Selene Luna, Diamondback Annie and Dizzy Von Damn. (Venusdemille.net)

Venus is also designer and tailor to Prince Poppycock, having created many of the costumes that were seen during his meteoric rise on America’s Got Talent.

Recently she has been building Superhero and Supervillain costumes for Batgirl the Web Series, collaborated with Austin Young on both the Fallen Fruit project and Tranimal, and worked with Michael Schmidt Studios to help construct the first fully articulated 3-D Printed dress worn by Dita Von Teese.

Website: SharonMcG.com

-------------------------------------------

Phranc

Phranc refers to herself as the "all-American Jewish lesbian folksinger" and the "Cardboard Cobbler." As a teenager, she attended the Feminist Studio Workshop at the Woman's Building where she studied printing and design. She then went on to perform as a member of several punk bands including Catholic Discipline, and Nervous Gender. She has toured internationally with many acclaimed and notorious artists such as The Knitters, The Smiths, The Pogues, and Morrissey. Later she returned to her acoustic roots. She has recorded 5 albums. Both her music and visual work employ humor to raise consciousness, trigger response, stimulate memories, and provoke discussion. Phranc is a former artist-in-residence at the 18th Street Arts Center in Santa Monica and a recipient of the 2007 C.O.L.A. Fellowship. She was featured in a solo exhibition in 2008 at CUE Art Foundation in NYC.
Phranc had her first major West Coast solo show, at Craig Krull Gallery, June 18 to July 23, 2011, an exhibition made of beach themed cardboard and kraft paper works. She continues to work in her Santa Monica studio and is represented by Krull.

See also: Phranc
 
-------------------------------------------

Art and Olfaction:

The Institute for Art and Olfaction was founded in October of 2012 by Saskia Wilson-Brown, with the assistance of a crackerjack team of advisors and Creative Director Micah Hahn. In December of 2012 the IAO was joined by Kóan Jeff Baysa, who came on to serve as the organization’s Programming Director. The IAO opened its Los Angeles headquarters at L.A. Mart, in March 2013. The Institute for Art and Olfaction is devoted to creative experimentation with a focus on scent. Our goal is to create new points of entry for people interested in the field of olfaction, while accommodating creative ideas in all mediums.

http://artandolfaction.com/

-------------------------------------------

Brent Leonesio

Brent Leonesio is an artist, perfumer and the creator of the indie scent-maker smell bent. In 2009, Leonesio began smell bent with little more than his unemployment checks and a playful dream. But smell bent proved to be more than a dream, and his passion project soon became his career. Since then, Brent’s work has found an audience on a global scale, and his whimsical scents have made fans both on the Internet and in the retail market. His work has grown to encompass fine fragrance, gallery work, artistic collaborations, custom and commercial formulations, teaching and recently, the creation of a smell bent comic book.
smellbent.com

-------------------------------------------

WIFE

WIFE, A Trinity of Illusory Performance Makers, is an all sensory theatrical experience born of three Los Angeles based artists, Jasmine Albuquerque, Kristen Leahy, and Nina McNeely. Her creations combine surrealist animations via projection mapping, sculpture, original music and costumes, using movement and dance as the vehicle for storytelling. WIFE harnesses old and new technology (magic) to illuminate enduring mystical phenomena and ancient archetypes that resonate throughout humankind’s collective unconscious. She is as a magician of picture and light, of movement and sound, reflecting rescued dreams and the subtleties of human behavior. She is the daughter, sister, and mother of all people set apart. She has been seen at Honor Fraser Gallery, Los Angeles Contemporary Exhibitions (LACE), Human Resources, Forum Lounge at Santa Barbara Contemporary Arts Forum, Dripped Fashion Show, Pieter, The El Portal Theatre, and the Bootleg Dance Festival 2011. WIFE’s “The Grey Ones” was presented at the Long Beach TEDx SoCal event, and is also featured on the electronic music artist Amon Tobin’s box set DVD. WIFE was awarded the ARC grant from the Center for Cultural Innovation in the fourth quarter of 2011. Abaddon, WIFE's full-length dance/projection theater piece, was featured in Native Strategies, a biannual journal and platform for performance art in Los Angeles. Most recently, WIFE was commissioned by Ford, Milk + Legs to create new work for an immersive gallery experience in NYC and LA that showcased five multimedia artists.

Website: wifewifewife.com

-------------------------------------------

 

Maker City LA:

An experiment in progress dedicated to creating the ﬁrst complete creative ecosystem with all the tools makers and creatives need to be successful in the global marketplace. Or maker tools, broadcast tools, seminars, events, the perfect place to collaborate and create. We’re starting with 60,000sf, but our vision is big - to create a Maker City for creatives, a community center for artists and artisans, a dream factory. We invite diverse and category busting creatives to join our community.

Rent a desk, rent a studio space, schedule a tour... Contact us for details!

info@makercityla.com

http://makercityla.com
story_txt:
What is TBD?!
 
Austin Young is proud to announce the launch of his latest project, TBD: A Musical Play and Video by EVERYONE Who Comes.
 
In contrast to the exclusivity of Hollywood or Broadway productions, this is a musical emphasizing radical authenticity and spontaneous creativity, and will be the most unusual and revolutionary musical you have ever experienced.  For this production, Austin Young invites the public to join in for a series 7 workshops where twe will co-create, sharing our stories and experiences around the topic of  ‘coming of age’  and produce a beautiful, unconventional, experimental and collaborative musical about everyone who comes. Our shared experiences during this time will become a co-authored  feature length video, and an illustrated screenplay. all staring you!
 
How it is Happening
 
There will be a series of 7 workshops over 3 weeks where the public is invited to become co-creators by attending one or more workshops during the run of the production.  Each workshop will become a musical number in the final feature  video documentation. 
To participate think of a story about growing up. It can be yours or someone else’s that had an influence on. Sign up for the workshop of your choice. What would you prefer to do: dance, sing, play music, and/or make costumes? You’ll receive a list of instructions.  Have fun. Be yourself.  It’s that easy!
 
WORKSHOPS: from July 20th to August 9rd.  workshops are free to the public. *there is an expense fee for the scent workshop.
WORKSHOP LEADERS and CONTRIBUTORS:
Abby Travis
Nina Mcneelly -
Squeaky Blonde 
Fade-Dra
FOL CHEN
Austin Young- 
Lenora Claire
Machine Project
 BEACH  (aka Bitch)
Juliana Snapper
Margaret Cho
The Killsisters 
Phranc
 Miller Puckette
The Heathers
TRANIMAL Workshop
Cake and Eat It
Institute for Art and Olfaction
Smell Bent
Accident
WIFE
Sharon McGunigle Aka Venus DeMille
Makeup provided by MAC cosmetics
Workshops space provided by Maker City LA and Machine Project Gallery
Video by Kurt Keppeler and Austin Young
Chloë Flores
 
What We Need
Your help is greatly needed! The more you can give, the more fabulous this will be. To make this project successful, I need to rent lighting and camera equpment. I will need to pay workshop leaders and provide needed supplies like fabric, clothes, mask making materials, paint, digital storage, a stenographer, and props as well as drinks and refreshments. I will need to hire a graphic designer to help put the screenplay in manuscript form, pay a video editor to edit the footage collected, and pay assistants to organize the photos and ephemera collected during the show. 
It's a lot but I know we can do it!
 
 TBD Workshops:  email austin@austinyoung.com with TBD in the subject line and list your top choices for the workshops you'd like to attend. When your workshop is confirmed, you will receive instructions on how to participate.
 
Saturday, July 20th (12-7pm) :  Things Unspoken with Juliana Snapper / Miller Puckette/ TRANIMAL Workshop (Squeaky Blonde, Fade-Dra and Austin Young)
Vocal performance, art. : In this workshop we will use costumes, sound, body and voice to express what words can't convey . Your pain. Your desires. Your shame. Your anger. Your obsessions. Your heartbreak.Your silence and noise. Your fear. Your alienation. Your desolation.Your ID.Then give it up to your inner TRANIMAL . (limited to 6 participants)
Monday, July 29th (6–9pm):  Smells Like Teen Spirit with The Institute for Art and Olfaction
Scent workshop, story telling: Write down a secret from your youth. Put it in a hat. Someone else will read it. Create a perfume for your inner teenager. (limited to 8 participants. there is a fee for materials sign up here: http://teenspirit.eventbrite.com/ )
 
Thursday, August 1st (12-8pm):  The Halls of My Highschool with Beach (aka Bitch)  / styling by Cake and Eat It.
Singing, dancing, acting: The halls of high school are like a war zone. Bring a hall pass and a note from your mother, a high school hallway (or hallway adjacent) story to share, and, if it involves props, to bring those too! (limited to 15 participants)
 
Saturday, August 3rd (3-8pm) :  Coming of Age with Nina Mcneely
Dancing: When hormones go wild, love is a battlefield ... bring a friend. (limited to 30 participants)
 
Sunday, August 4th  (2-8pm): Campfire Crush with Phranc
Story telling, singing:  It's summer camp. It can get cold. bring proper camp attire and a flashlight.  Who are you crushed out on? I've been thinking of all the camp songs I know. Especially that tune mentioning the "calf with the mournful eye". Remember that one?? Oy! (limited to 15 participants)
 
August 7th and 8th (5-10 pm):  Who Am I (part 1 and 2) with Fol Chen / Machine Project / Austin Young / costumes provided by Sharon McGunigle
Story telling, singing:  bring a pop song and a story that stands out when you were coming of age. Who am i? Don't dream it. Be it!  I'm punk rock. I'm new wave.  I'm straight. I'm gay. I'm cool.  (limited to 10 participants- you must attend both workshops)
 
August 9th: Slumber Party (2-12pm) - KILLSISTERS / WIFE / ACCIDENT/ hosted by Lenora Claire    (Final workshop, and launch of Austin Young’s 'Accident', by Brent Leonesio, an art edition of 100 scents created with The Institute for Art and Olfaction).Singing, dancing, acting, story telling:  Pillow fights. Ouiji boards. Toilet Paper. Light as a feather, stiff as a board. Truth or dare. Spin the bottle. Roulette chat. Facebook stalking. Three-way calls.  We will act out our slumber party stories. bring necessary props. (no limit to participants) 
A Little Bit of Background  
 
Austin young is a pop-culture architect, photographer and trans media artist. Young has been documenting pop, celebrity, sub, and trans culture since 1985 through portraiture. Young's video works play with pop-culture and camp, celebrity, gender and identity. His photographs have been featured in major publications such as Interview Magazine, OK, and Flaunt and have been in solo exhibitions and projects at LACMA (Los Angeles, CA), Machine Project (Los Angeles, CA), Hammer Museum (Los Angeles, CA), Berkeley Art Museum (Berkley, California); and as well as groups shows at Los Angeles Contemporary Exhibitions (Los Angeles, CA) and Stephen Cohen Gallery (Los Angeles, CA).  They have been shown at festivals including Frameline, MIX.  In addition to photography and filmmaking, Young is co-founder of Fallen Fruit, an art collective who use fruit as a common denominator to change the way you think about the world. Fallen Fruit has had major exhibitions at Los Angeles County Museum of Art; Hammer Museum; Salt Lake Art Center (Salt Lake City, Utah), Machine Project, Matadero (Madrid, Spain); LACE (Los Angeles) and ARS Electronic (Austria). Fallen Fruit is a Creative Capital grantee for 2013 and just completed LA counties first public fruit park in Del Aire with a grant from the LA County Art's commission.
 
austinyoung.com
 -------------------------------------------

 
Fol Chen
Fol Chen has created a signature sound from field recordings and an electronic junk drawer, building compound beats and sending warped vocal transmissions. Led by producers Samuel Bing and Julian Wass, Fol Chen's first two records, PART I: John Shade, Your Fortune's Made (Asthmatic Kitty, 2009) and PART II: The New December (Asthmatic Kitty, 2010), cemented the band's place as peddlers of dark pop in the alleys of independent music. Their live entity has a wide artistic reach with a propensity for interactive projects like the Tetrafol, a motion-based sound toy developed with musical interface pioneers Monome. Band events have been presented at sites such as the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, the Annenberg Space for Photography, and the Walker Art Center.
THE FALSE ALARMS out now on Asthmatic Kitty Records: www.bit.ly/fol_chen_4sale

WIFE harnesses old and new technology (magic) to illuminate enduring mystical phenomena and ancient archetypes that resonate throughout humankind’s collective unconscious. She is as a magician of picture and light, of movement and sound, reflecting rescued dreams and the subtleties of human behavior. She is the daughter, sister, and mother of all people set apart. She has been seen at Honor Fraser Gallery, Los Angeles Contemporary Exhibitions (LACE), Human Resources, Forum Lounge at Santa Barbara Contemporary Arts Forum, Dripped Fashion Show, Pieter, The El Portal Theatre, and the Bootleg Dance Festival 2011. WIFE’s “The Grey Ones” was presented at the Long Beach TEDx SoCal event, and is also featured on the electronic music artist Amon Tobin’s box set DVD. WIFE was awarded the ARC grant from the Center for Cultural Innovation in the fourth quarter of 2011. Abaddon, WIFE's full-length dance/projection theater piece, was featured in Native Strategies, a biannual journal and platform for performance art in Los Angeles. Most recently, WIFE was commissioned by Ford, Milk + Legs to create new work for an immersive gallery experience in NYC and LA that showcased five multimedia artists.Website: wifewifewife.com 
-------------------------------------------
 

Maker City LA:
An experiment in progress dedicated to creating the ﬁrst complete creative ecosystem with all the tools makers and creatives need to be successful in the global marketplace. Or maker tools, broadcast tools, seminars, events, the perfect place to collaborate and create. We’re starting with 60,000sf, but our vision is big - to create a Maker City for creatives, a community center for artists and artisans, a dream factory. We invite diverse and category busting creatives to join our community.
Rent a desk, rent a studio space, schedule a tour... Contact us for details!
info@makercityla.com
http://makercityla.com

story:
Trevor Knott has worked diligently to create artworks that represent processes of personal transformation and rituals of spiritual harmony. Primarily using a mixture of water, charcoal, and consciousness, he works to produce art in the studio as well as the natural world that is a visual manifestation of the meditative effort and a tribute to the elements at play. Though these works are documented, they are often left behind for others to discover and give meaning to. With this art he hopes to elucidate the strange beauty of transformation and provide spaces that help facilitate a reflective mentality.

Trevor has recently been awarded a space at The Old School Residency in Gorna Lipnitsa, Bulgaria in the month of August. While there, he and seven other international artists will work to create an exhibition that focuses on ritual and elements unique to that region. Being accepted into this residency is a major milestone in his artistic career--marking his first international exhibition and residency grant--now he just needs help getting there.

His current plan is to create a large ceremonial fire for the people of Gorna Lipnitsa to contribute an offering to the land. This will generate a large amount of charcoal which will then be used to create a mark in the landscape that resonates with its surroundings. In doing so, the artist hopes to create further dialogue that harmonizes the relationship between the land and its inhabitants.

On his return, Trevor will share his experiences and artwork at the post-residency party on September 21st*. The funds gathered through this project will mostly go to airfare and ground transport. Any additional funding will go towards creating similar projects in the Midwest that will also be shared with contributors.

*Tickets for party will be available for purchase at the event. VIP tickets allow access to special raffle.

story:
WHAT NOW?

Emma Katz at Recession Art has invited me to attend the Wassaic Project Artist Residency through the Recession Art / Wassaic Project partnership this coming April, and I would totally love to join the other three artists they have invited.  The residency costs $600 for the session running from April 2nd- April 30th, 2014, along with a $300 deposit.  I'll need to make the payment towards the residency on October 1st, and I'll be putting the rest of the money raised towards film & development costs, as well as printing costs.


A little about me:  

I'm a queer photographer whose work examines the tension between representation and presentation, between the traditionally singular desire inherent in the photographer’s gaze, and the mutual desires involved in cruising, one night stands, and other casual encounters.  I recently finished my MFA in Photography at Columbia College Chicago, and just moved back to New York.  I now live and work in Brooklyn.  I like milk shakes in pretty much any weather condition, Roseanne, and My Bloody Valentine.   Funding through this campaign will go towards both the costs of the residency itself (roughly $900 for a one month stay) and towards the cost of supplies used in the production of a new series of images.


WHAT ARE YOU SPENDING MY MONEY ON?

So here's the breakdown of how much the Wassaic Project Artist Residency will cost:

  • One month stay at the Wassaic Project from April 2nd to April 30th, 2014 - $600.  Includes room + board in one of their houses in addition to a studio space.
  • Security Deposit - $300. (Due with cost of residency on October 1st)
  • 5 boxes of Fuji Provia 4x5 Slide Film (20 sheets each) - $350
  • Developing 100 sheets of slide film at LTI/Lightside Photographic Services - $300


WHY SHOULD I GIVE YOU MY MONEY?

Funding would allow me to attend a residency program for the first time, allowing me both the opportunity to make work in a beautiful mountain setting and exposing my work to curators and critics who have no idea who I am otherwise.  It will also allow me time to explore ideas of gender, collaboration, and the muse, within the larger confines of my ongoing project A Momentary Interaction.  I will also send you awesome things, depending on how many clams you send me, such as:

  • $25 gets you a copy of my zine A Momentary Interaction and a 5x7" print of the image used in the campaign, Mark and I at the Beach (After Brooke Shields), at an edition of 20.
  • $50 gets you a copy of my zine A Momentary Interaction and an 8x10" print of the image used in the campaign, Mark and I at the Beach (After Brooke Shields), at an edition of 10.
  • $100 gets you a copy of my zine A Momentary Interaction and an 16x20" print of the image used in the campaign, Mark and I at the Beach (After Brooke Shields), at an edition of 2.

GURL, I GOT BILLS TO PAY.

Any help is good!  If you can't help with cash, spreading the word is always welcome:

  • Share this on facebook, tumblr, and through email - however you see fit!
  • The Indiegogo share tools are easy and convenient!  Give a signal boost!

Thanks in advance!  <3 <3 <3

Gregg

http://greggevans.net

http://annotatedimages.tumblr.com

story:
About Me

There is a lot I could tell you about myself, but what matters is that I am a creator and community-builder. I have worked as a visual artist, a writer, an editor, a dancer, a capoeirista, a teacher. In all of my work I try to use language and connection to try to build a better and more equitable world. During my undergraduate career, I have come to decide that design is the most exciting and effective way for me to do that professionally, but have struggled to integrate that into the overwhelmingly historically corporate, profit-driven atmosphere of the professional design world at large. However, in recent years, other narratives about design have begun to emerge and gather steam. As I prepare to graduate and hurtle into an increasingly pre-apocalyptic world, I hope that my senior thesis project—an accumulation of my artistic and academic education at Wesleyan—will provide a foundation for my career and practice as a professional designer that foregrounds my passion for connectivity and reflection within the field.

 

About ExpoNOW

My thesis, ExpoNOW, is an examination of how the commodification of time and experience constructs identity and belonging amidst and among global social, political, and technological networks. Inspired by the history of world's fairs and their impact on the development of the globalized and networked world we live in today, ExpoNOW draws upon and critiques contemporary practices of branding, exhibition design, and marketing. It will take the form of an exhibition inspired by world expositions and trade shows, where the content of the exposition is the viewer themselves, in the present moment.

 

Here's where you come in.

The fabrication and construction of any project of this scale has a huge material cost as well as a time cost. I've got the time (not enough, but a lot), but I don't have the money. I need to cover my materials costs for printing and building the displays in my exhibition, and for fabricating the exhibition's ephemera, which is an essential demonstration of the brand design's success and execution.

Some things I am making:

  • Trade Show Display
  • Large hanging banners and graphics
  • Brochures
  • T-Shirts
  • Postcards
  • Buttons
  • Tote bags
  • Expo badges

All of these have a material and fabrication cost that my own savings cannot cover. This fundraiser is not only a way to cover those costs, it is also a way for you to have a piece of ExpoNOW for yourself. It doubles as an e-gift-shop of sorts for the expo's branded goods.

I am not trying to make a profit from any of these products. The amount I am trying to raise covers all of my anticipated material costs for creating my ideal exhibition, with $300 padding to accommodate for the expenses I haven't calculated yet, but know will come up— namely the cost of plywood and paper for my the pavilion construction. Indiegogo also takes 5% of whatever I raise, and I hope to somewhat offset that.

Any leftover funds will be donated to 826 Valencia, an educational and creative writing nonprofit that has been instrumental in my growth and development, and has funded part of my own Wesleyan education.

 

The Impact

When I realized I wanted to be a designer, I had a painful deliberation about whether or not I should transfer to a design school for their greater course offerings and professional resources. However, I chose to stay at Wesleyan because I realized that critical thought and interdisciplinary practice was not only essential to who I am as a person, but also because I decided that it was essential to being the best designer I can be. I needed the array of perspectives, knowledge, and skill that a liberal arts education would offer. I have never regretted that decision, but have had to be resourceful, independent, and tenacious in my education, and am admittedly graduating at certain disadvantages compared to peers who attended design schools. I have fewer connections, and a far more limited portfolio. This is why my thesis is essential to my future job prospects. The scope of the Wesleyan art theses provides possibilities and opportunities unavailable at many undergraduate schools. ExpoNOW will be the cornerstone of my portfolio after graduation, and the more fully I am able to realize it, the more it will help compensate for my different set of experiences and skills than art school graduate job applicants. The less I have to worry about overhead materials costs, the more successfully I will be able to realize the project and continue to contribute to essential discourses about the future role and impact of design on a world that needs transparency and equality more than ever.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't donate, please share this fundraiser with your own networks to help get the word out! Truly every penny counts. Thank you all so much for reading.

story:
Short Summary

Hello fellow sponsors!

I am a proud graduate of the University of Alabama Birmingham with a Bachelors in Theatre Arts.  I am a member of the Aurora Theatre Professional Acting Apprenticeship Company Class of 2018. I was selected to be a director for the 2019 Alumni Series based on my submission of Dutchman. In this series, directors are expected to self produce a play production. Everything from casting and  production team to marketing and fundraising is completely the responsibility of the director. 

I believe that pictures are worth a thousand words and for me in art we get tons of pictures with a million words, out of one piece. 1960 to 2019 has quite a few similarities. One of the many  reasons I chose Dutchman. From my very first time reading it in undergrad, until being called upon to partake in this great opportunity. It has always left me with many answers. I hope that this piece as others holds true to the saying that a picture is worth a thousand words and spark what ever conversation needs to be had. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking you to help us raise at least $3000.

These funds will aid in the following:

  • Set design/build- materials and labor
  • Lighting 
  • Sound 
  • Props 
  • Costumes
  • Marketing- photography/print
  • Artist Appreciation- Choreographer, Actors, Stage Management, Stage Hand

 

The Impact

The world is full of assimilation where people try to be something that they are not; constantly trying to fit in, in a world that they don't belong to. This world is full of separation and judgement of things and people we don't understand. Differences in race and culture has always caused confusion and discourse from the late 1800's to the 60's and into the millennium. Dutchman is a story that depicts what happens when prejudice and stereotypes are confronted and how the choices that we make in life can affect both the individual and the community. 

 

    Risks & Challenges

    If we fail to reach our goal, we would still get this production on its feet but it would not be at its fullest potential. I want all artists who collaborated  and trusted the success of this process to feel appreciated for the work they are contributing as well.  I will be donating personal funds to the project to ensure they do. 

     

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Please share and use this Indiegogo  link to get the word out to your family, friends, and anyone who would appreciate this production.

story:
We now live in a world that is wired, and we understand that innovation is key to the success and future of Oakland, Pittsburgh, and our region.

Home to some of the world’s top research, educational, medical and cultural institutions, Oakland is determined to be America’s first Digital District. Working with several local and regional partners, we have planned Pittsburgh’s first digital Infrastructure project called Innovation Oakland.  

Can you imagine a city designed to complement your new technology driven lifestyle?  A city where you will never be lost, where “Welcome Centers” are new interactive touch screens located on a public sidewalk providing real-time information about events, museum exhibitions, or where to find that Thai lunch you are hungry for.  Where robots guide the visually and hearing impaired visitors in and around our hospitals and universities.  A city where you know exactly where to park, thanks to the real time parking space information provided to you via a digital screen in view as you drive along Forbes Avenue.  Imagine attending a concert or basketball game in Oakland where the street lights, street signs, and banners can all be changed instantly to reflect event information and guidance - all controlled remotely from a laptop.  A city where public art installations match the mood and event of the moment: the Pitt Panthers just won and the Boulevard of the Allies Bridge is changed into a blue and gold tunnel of light.  A city where digital illiteracy no longer divides people- everyone will participate and benefit from the new economy.  A city that becomes a global destination for tourists who travel to experience the “Digital District”.

Innovation Oakland (IO) seeks to build this and more. IO will combine information, art, place-making and way-finding solutions to create smart infrastructures solutions that will attract new users into our community and that will:

  • Ensure that Oakland's infrastructure  reflects the City of Pittsburgh's international reputation as an Innovative City
  • Brand a regional identity that reflects innovation
  • Foster and celebrate technological developments happening in Oakland's research institutions
  • Eliminate the Digital Divide by providing the entire population access to digital technology
  • Improve navigation and way finding to benefit all community matters
  • Stimulate neighborhood and business revitalization
  • Create exciting and vibrant destination spaces that reflect the 21st century
  • Provide a pedestrian-focused signage and navigation system
  • Promote the Oakland community
  • Showcase Oakland’s assets

The IO Digital Art Gallery will be the first step into turning the Oakland neighborhood into an innovation community.

Guided by new technology and cutting edge design, the IO Digital Art Gallery will be an example of a 21st century dynamic space!  Located at the highly visible corner of Forbes Avenue and South Bouquet Street, the pedestrian plaza site is accessible to the thousands of local residents, employees, students and visitors that populate Oakland daily.  

Thank you to the University of Pittsburgh for making this remarkable site available for a period of time as the initial location of the digital gallery!  The digital gallery improvements (including all recognition) are subject to removal at the end of the period of availability.  Should the digital gallery change locations and be moved elsewhere, all recognition will also be moved to a new visible location.

The Plaza will include:

  • A series of state of the art digital canvases, LED screens that display "real time" information for the public (ex: bus arrival and departure & incident management messages), promotion of local events and Oakland happenings and video streaming
  • New energy efficient “smart” light poles that have sound capability
  • Wi-Fi
  • New pavers and benches
  • Rain Garden to include native plant-scapes

The Digital Art Gallery will be managed by world renowned curator Murray Horne, who is also the curator of the Wood Street Gallery in Downtown Pittsburgh’s Cultural District. The IO outdoor Digital Art Gallery will be the first of it kind in the US and will feature local, national and international artists.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We already have the components to make this Digital Art Gallery a reality, right now, what we need is the funding to install it.  With such technologies, we need to cover the cost of a construction team to install this exciting system.
  • By helping to make this a reality, we want to make sure that you are rewarded!  Not only will you have a great destination to visit in our neighborhood and experience world-class digital art and updates on community happenings, but you will also receive a great thank you gift!  All contributions will be made to Community Human Services to directly benefit the IO Digital Art Gallery.
  • We are so excited to have your support!  At the close of this campaign (September 30th) we will follow up with you and customize your recognition to reflect exactly what you want it to be, that means that if you make a gift that will result in a brick paver, we will make sure it reflects the message you would like, that could be your name, your company name, or a short phrase.

New energy efficient “smart” light poles that have sound capability
Wi-Fi
New pavers and benches
Rain Garden to include native plant-scapes
The Digital Art Gallery will be managed by world renowned curator Murray Horne, who is also the curator of the Wood Street Gallery in Downtown Pittsburgh’s Cultural District. The IO outdoor Digital Art Gallery will be the first of it kind in the US and will feature local, national and international artists.   What We Need & What You Get 
We already have the components to make this Digital Art Gallery a reality, right now, what we need is the funding to install it.  With such technologies, we need to cover the cost of a construction team to install this exciting system.
By helping to make this a reality, we want to make sure that you are rewarded!  Not only will you have a great destination to visit in our neighborhood and experience world-class digital art and updates on community happenings, but you will also receive a great thank you gift!  All contributions will be made to Community Human Services to directly benefit the IO Digital Art Gallery.
We are so excited to have your support!  At the close of this campaign (September 30th) we will follow up with you and customize your recognition to reflect exactly what you want it to be, that means that if you make a gift that will result in a brick paver, we will make sure it reflects the message you would like, that could be your name, your company name, or a short phrase.

story:
Short Summary

We are introduced as a couple from Croatia whose profession can be directly described as illustrators, painters and drawers. Our inspiration comes from the beauty of our nature and environment, the luminosity of our everyday surroundings , as well as, the tragedy and comedy within the human life. Our path has led us to the creation of wooden coasters for cups, plates and other serving dishes. However, this is not where our journey ends as we find pleasure in experimenting with wood  as well as recycling wooden objects.

Our vision defines wood in terms of environmental cleanliness and purity as this material shines with positive energy and warmth while also being perfectly adaptable to any home environment and decorative style.

Our motive and topic of our creation is evident through our picturesque illustrations of traditional Croatian sayings and inspirational quotes. Our hope is to provide a glimpse of Croatian culture and tradition through these illustrations of our folk sayings and quotes. Furthermore, our mission is to make your everyday special starting with the morning coffee that you drink- our coasters will separate you from your potentially-hectic-everyday routine and remind you that there is a lighter way.

However, not only as a personally used product, we can say with certainty that as a souvenir for your loved ones, our products are not dust-collecting objects but rather serve its full purpose and potential. Our products are an ideal one-of-it's-kind detail in every kitchen and can also be a unique gift to anyone.


What We Need & What You Get

The above is who we are and what we do. In order to accomplish our mission, the following resources are needed. Below if our proposal to Indiegogo.

  • Opening of a physical lab of creative ideas

  • Purchase of tools for imaging (burning of the wood)

  • Purchase of tools for crafting of the wood

  • Purchase of a number of wooden surfaces for crafting/imaging (scraps of wood)

  • Purchase of water-based colors for the imaging (Eco-friendly)

  • Building of the company web-page and web-shop for the marketing of our products and services

The Impact

Everyone's amount will be certainly well spent, and in return it will be our honor to reward you.

10$ or more
Thank you! You will receive thanksgiving card with illustration on your e-mail.

25 $ or more

Thank you! You will get illustration in a format for printing on t-shirt or you can make a sticker for your wall. We will send it to your e-mail as well

50 $ or more

Thank you very much! Do you have any photo that you allways wanted to convert to illustrate? Here's your chance! Send us your photo by email, and we'll make an illustration and send back to you in printing available format.

120 $ or more

Thank you very much! Please send us any proverb or wisdom, and we will paint it, make an illustration or comic that you will also be able to print out and stick on the wall, frame, etc.

240 $ or more

Thank you, thank you a lot. You can choose. We want you to introduce with our work. Please give us your full home address and we will send you our wooden gift with surprise picture. In the same email attach one of your photo or wisdom that you want to illustrate and you will get one too. As another option we will send you a bag.




380 $ or more

Many, many thanks. Of course we'd be honored to send you our unique gifts. We will do it, just send us your home address. Expect painted wooden gift that will arrive in one of our bags. That means, we send you bag and wooden gift. Since we live in the most beautiful Mediterranean country expect some natural motive. You'll carve your gifts special thanks for your contribution. 



500 $ or more

THANK YOU the most! You are the best and you have the best prize. We don't want to miss show you our unique handcrafts. But before all, we want to know if you have any photo you like the most with always wanted motive? Send us by email. It will be drawn to your gift and you will get unique bag beside as well.




1400 $ or more

We are speechless. How to say thank you to be enough? You are the very best. Do you have any wish to be transferred to the canvas? Photo or portrait wouldn't be a bad idea?


2500 $ or more

OMG, you are the BOSS and you will have treatment you deserve! You'll get a full paid summer holiday with full paid accommodation in city of Rijeka, Croatia.

Yes, you have read well, fully paid holidays with accommodation, can you believe? You will support our project and we we'll give you free holiday on the most 

desirable location on the planet this summer. This includes 7 days in a villa with swimming pool and spacious green area for stress relief treatment. Only 5 km away from your accommodation you can swim in the clearest and the most beautiful sea in the world. Bring your family, friends or society, up to 6 member. Because of your payment, accomodation for all of them will be totally free. We can send you pictures of your summers destination if you want it.

Other Ways You Can Help

Show your friends, family and colleagues our project. We will be glad when each of you recognize our potential.

story:
Short Summary

Researching for an alternative approach to art/creative practice in Singapore.


What We Need & What You Get

The fund is to assist the rental fees for an alternative space for a month (October 2016).  This space will be reserved for a group of art practitioners to research, explore and experiment with curiosity and to manifest it into ideas that will be shared.

Invited participants for this project are on volunteer basis.

More images and videos will be updated here while the participants of the project continue to progress through the process.


Why this project?

Too often, when one is approaching a creative work, one has to develop a propose idea before the actual work begins.

What if one is given time and space to immerse in the process without a proposed outcome?

This project serves as a seed to re-discover a possibility of an alternative approach to creative work.  Participants will be given time and space to work and to create, from nothing (not even a proposed idea) to something. 

Let the outcome be a surprise-element from the search and research process.  Let the process be process.

PS:  That is why for this project, the image is a "blank" as we have no idea what it is going to be.  At least not till we begin our work.


Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Come join us in October if any ideas is manifested.
  • Pass the word around to people you know who might be interested to support.


Participants

  • Lee Yeong Wen (Facilitator)
  • Lim Chin Huat
  • Julius Foo
  • Dorothy Png
  • Koh WanChing
  • Seow Yiqing
  • Pamela Lee
  • Doreen Toh
  • Felicia Lim
  • Pima Yeung

Thank you for taking time with this :)

story:
I am Danielle Barlow,  a painter, illustrator  and incense maker, living and working on Dartmoor, in the south west of the UK.

 

 

I grew up here in Devon before training in the creative arts, and then in horticulture, and I've always juggled these two passions, fascinated by how these skills helped to connect our ancestors very profoundly to the land in which they lived. These days I work primarily in ink and watercolour. Deeply rooted in this ancient landscape of ours, my work draws heavily on folklore and mythology, and explores the deep connection, both physical and spiritual, between people and the land they inhabit.

 

I have spent the last 5 years creating The Green Wheel Oracle Deck, a set of 45 cards from my paintings. This is a set of divination cards that can be used in several ways:  to offer insights into situations, to suggest new ways of looking at things, and also to help you journey deeper into an awareness of the rythyms of the land and the skies.

The deck is divided into three sets: The 8 Wheel cards, which follow the wheel of the year, and mark the 8 celtic festivals - Imbolc, Spring Equinox, Beltane, Midsummer, Lammas, Autumn Equinox, Samhain and Midwinter.  The 13 Moon cards, representing the thirteen lunar months of the year, and 24 Companion cards, depicting animal and plant allies.

Finally, after years of work, it is ready to be put into production. I am working with a local print company, and we plan to produce a set of beautiful full coloured, high quality cards (89mm x 127mm) which will come with a cloth bag and a small book explaining how to work with the cards, in a beautiful presentation box.

Why do I need your help?

I want to produce this myself, rather than handing it to a publisher, because it's an intensely personal project, and I want to retain control of the content. It's taken me five years of hard work, with no financial return on the project, and I'd like to publish it myself.  What I'm doing here is launching it as a pre-order - so that the advance payments will fund the printing. I know that many of my customers have been patiently waiting for years to get their hands on a copy of this deck, and so I am offering the Green Wheel Oracle at a special pre-order price of £35 plus postage (please check the pre-order perks to make sure you choose the one with the correct postage for your country). This pre-orders should be ready to post by the end of November, meaning it can be ordered in time for Christmas. The size of the print run will be determined by the funding raised, but I am hoping to make an edition of 1000 units, which I plan to launch on the retail market later in the New Year.

 

 

What's the money for?

 

I need to raise £10,000 to bring this to production:

£7000 for print and production costs

£1000 covers the percentage to Indiegogo, campaign costs, and pre-production samples (plus a small fee to my 12 year old nephew, Ruan Scott for his expertise and hard work in video creating and editing and tech advice!)

£2000 approx will cover the postage and packing of pre-orders and perks

What am I offering in return?

As well as the options for pre-ordering a deck, there are lots of exciting perks you can buy too!

  • Special 'limited edition' sets of the Green Wheel Oracle, including extra tools for working with the deck, such as incense to use with the lunar months, and a beautiful handmade casting cloth
  • Small sets of Altar cards and incense
  • Limited edition large giclee prints of the 8 Wheel Cards
  • An incense making workshop (in the south west of UK) for up to 6 people
  • Some original paintings from the deck to be released for sale later in the campaign

What happens if I don't meet my target?

All the pre-orders and perks will be fulfilled, however much the campaign raises, BUT I will have to make a much smaller print run, and therefore am unlikely to have decks to sell after the pre-orders or to launch into shops in the New Year.

And if I go over?

There is so much more I can do with more funds! My priority will be framing the original artwork for exhibition and launch of the Green Wheel Oracle. This will cost about £2500. Extra funds would be put towards the launch and marketing campaign, and updating my website.

 

 

Is there any risk involved?

The risks are small for this project, as most of the work is already done. However, I haven't quite finished writing the small book that goes with the deck. I am confident that I can complete this by the middle of October, when the campaign finishes, and the project is ready to go to the printers. The printers, a very experienced company, have assured me that they can deliver the separate elements of the product within a month from giving them the go ahead, so I am confident it will be with me by the end of November. Then it will be all hands on deck with friends and family to assemble it, pack it, and post out pre-orders in time for Christmas!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

I know it's not always possible to contribute financially, but that doesn't matter. You can make a huge difference to this by sharing it as far and wide as you can. Please use the indiegogo sharing tools to spread the message as much as you can.

Thankyou SO much .

story:
SourceURL:file://localhost/Users/Dexter/Downloads/Indiegogo%20edit.docx

Indiegogo updates

 

My name is Nik Wallenda, and I’m a 7th generation daredevil from the Flying Wallenda family. I spent the past 2 years working tirelessly to lobby governments in two countries and change laws that have been in place for over a hundred years. Why?  I wanted to achieve my life long dream and be the first person ever to walk across Niagara Falls on a tight rope. On June 15th, that dream came true.

 

I live my life following a simple but powerful mantra- never give up! In 1978 my grandfather fell to his death walking a tightrope between 2 buildings in Puerto Rico. I recently did that same walk in his memory.

 

Tight Rope is a performance art that has been passed down in our family for generations. It is the apex of engineering and personal discipline requiring strength and sharp mental focus to keep balanced on a tensioned wire between two points. Tightrope walking is a part of American history and has been a form of popular entertainment since the circuses of the 1700’s. With this walk over Niagara Falls I wanted to elevate and evolve the art, just as my personal hero and great-grandfather Karl Wallenda did with the 7 person chair pyramid Flying Wallendas.

 

So why am I on Indiegogo? I may be the first man to be granted the right to attempt the walk, but I’m not the first who tried to seek permission. It was a long and arduous process that at times felt impossible. With the miraculous support of my family, friends, local and federal government officials, a lot of patience and persistence we did the impossible… and now I’m coming to you, the Indiegogo community to be that last bit of support that makes this possible.

 

One of the conditions of the walk was that I had to finance it myself. No government assistance was provided and in fact I had to pay for all government services. We have been able to offset most of these costs but not all of them. The unforeseen costs that popped up last minute are huge. I’m coming to you Indiegogo. Be a part of this important moment in history. Help me compensate all of the people that made the impossible happen.

 

I am asking for your help in raising $50,000. Thanks to everyone who watched the walk, and for all of your support. It means the world to me.

 

FAQ's

This is so exciting! How else can I help?

Every bit of support helps! You can connect with me on Facebook and share this campaign with your friends. You can donate for one of the great rewards listed to the right. We are also willing to go above and beyond the listed rewards if you are! For donations above $10,000, we can work out something very special such as a high-wire walk in your home town. 

DSW Entertainment 212-974-5322

What is your fundraising goal? What will the money go to?

Our goal is $50,000. They money will go towards:

  • Training
  • Rigging
  • Marketing
  • Travel
  • Safety
  • Unforeseen issues

What happens if you don't reach your goal?

Don't let this happen, please! Any amount will help us cover our costs, but we really need to reach (and hopefully surpass!) our goal in order to pay everyone that made this happen!

 

If I donate, when will I receive my reward?

4-6 weeks after the walk is completed, we will contact you for your personal information, and send your reward right afterwards! 

Certain rewards, such as the book, will not be sent until they are available.

I want more information! How can I contact you?

Keep an eye on my Facebook page, look for me on your local and national news, and join me on June 15th as I walk across Niagara Falls! For any media, sponsorship, or business requests, please contact my management company:

DSW Entertainment 212-974-5322

Certain rewards, such as the book, will not be sent until they are available.
I want more information! How can I contact you?
Keep an eye on my Facebook page, look for me on your local and national news, and join me on June 15th as I walk across Niagara Falls! For any media, sponsorship, or business requests, please contact my management company:
DSW Entertainment 212-974-5322

story:
Do we really understand what the loss of 1,136 people really look like?

We find that it is images and concepts, more than words and quotes, that help people come closer to understanding and empowerment. The Golden Shoes Project is a street art installation of 1,136 Golden Shoes to illustrate through art what 1,136 people lost in 365 really looks like. May we not only honor those we lost but empower our island to come together against complacency and hopelessness.

What We Need & What You Get

We must raise $5,500 to get the necessary materials to create and display the installation.

Pledge $25- You get a beautiful postcard/picture of the exhibit! Send to your friends/family or frame it! (1st 100 pledges)

Pledge $100- You get A PART OF THE INSTALLATION! We will send you one pair of glittered shoes...your own piece of art! (1st 25 pledges)

 

The Impact

Through The Golden Shoes Project we hope to:

  • Honor those we lost to violence 
  • Create awareness and transform commiunities
  • Bring light to the violence problem in Puerto Rico
  • Be a stand for change
  • Turn human suffering into an energizing force against violence.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Volunteer
  • Donate shoes
  • Please check out our website at www.kilo365.com to see how you can be involved.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Karon Leigh.  I am an artist living in southeastern Arizona.  I moved to Arizona from the pacific northwest in 2008 for the sun and light.  What I found was incredible beauty, energy and creative inspiration.

Currently and historically, artists have made their way to the southwest for the light, the wide open spaces, the energy and the rich history of the American west.

Open Studio Tours are a unique opportunity to appreciate what its like to be an artist.  I am interested in how artists work in their spaces, how they set up their space for their particular medium and work style.

It is not my nature to ask for help.  I'm a very independent person and although I totally believe in community funded projects and what sites like Indiegogo can do, I am usually the giver, not the receiver.

So here's my project:

Southwest Art Studios is an ongoing project to visit, interview and document artist in their studios in Arizona and New Mexico and to create an online web based "Open Studio Tour" to help promote artists and share their studios and their work with the world.

Most artists don't make a living from selling their art.  Artists work in many fields and often juggle multiple jobs in or order to support their families, pay the bills, buy their art supplies and have time in the studio to create their art.  I am fortunate in that I am able to work in a creative field managing art programs for a small non-profit.  I spend time in the evenings and on weekends creating my art.  I also teach art workshops in encaustic painting and monotype printmaking.

My studio spaces have been a closet, a garage, a room in the house, the dining room table, a commercial space with other artists, a casita, and currently, a small area off of the kitchen in my house.  No matter where we set up to create our art, whether we are selling our work in galleries or working multiple jobs, what all artists share and have in common, is the passion and need to create.  It is who we are.

It is my love of art and artists that inspire me to create this project.  I think artists need to be supported and promoted.  Art is fundamental and critical to a civilized society.  Art Saves Lives!

In June of 2013 I am taking unpaid time off of work to visit and interview artists in New Mexico.  I will be documenting their studio spaces with photos and video.  I am creating a blog and website, www.SouthwestArtStudios.com to promote the artists that I visit.  In order to make all of this happen and get this project off the ground and onto the web, I need a little help from you to help offset my travel expenses.

Some of the scheduled artists studios:

Catherine Nash - Tucson, AZ

Greta Ward, Tucson, AZ

Adrienne Mehrens - Cerrillos, NM

Kevin Box - Cerrillos, NM

Ron Pokrasso - Santa Fe, NM

Paula Roland - Santa Fe, NM

Harriette Tsosie  - Albuquerque, NM

Donna Clair - Tesuque, NM

Donna Caulton - Chamisal, NM

Trish Booth - Truchas, NM

& the list is growing.

What I Need & What You Get

What I need your help with are the travel expenses I will incur while I take unpaid time off from work to travel through New Mexico during the last 2 weeks of June 2013 visiting and interviewing artists.

Not only do you support the artists I visit by allowing me to document their studios, you will be included in the project and on the SouthwestArtStudios.com website and will also receive a gift of my original art.  I will be creating art based on my travels and will send original works of art to my supporters.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help by:

Getting the word out and making some noise about supporting art and artists.

Use the Indiegogo share tools to share this campaign with friends and family.

And that’s all there is to it.  I greatly appreciate your support.
